title: hero doctors nick boris baby
story: THE hero doctors who Boris Johnson and Carrie Symonds named their son after have said they are honoured and humbled to be recognised. The Prime Minister and his fiancée today revealed today they had named their baby boy Wilfred Lawrie Nicholas in honour of Dr Nick Hart and Dr Nick Price.The pair are experts in infectious diseases and ventilation and were among the team to save Boris le as he battled coronavirus.The doctors said in a statement said: “Our warm congratulations go to the Prime Minister and Carrie Symonds on the happy arrival of their beautul son Wilfred.“We are honoured and humbled to have been recognised in this way, and we give our thanks to the incredible team of professionals who we work with at Guy’s and St Thomas’ and who ensure every patient receives the best care.“We wish the new family every health and happiness.”Carrie, , gave birth early Wednesday morning - just  days after Boris, , fought for his le in intensive care with coronavirus.And announcing her sons name, the new mum gushed on social media: Introducing Wilfred Lawrie Nicholas Johnson born on .. at am.Wilfred after Boris grandfather.Lawrie after my grandfather.Nicholas after Dr Nick Price and Dr Nick Hart - the two doctors that saved Boris le last month.Thank you so, so much to the incredible NHS maternity team at UCLH that looked after us so well.I couldnt be happier. My heart is full.Dr Nicholas Price is a consultant in infectious diseases and general medicine, according to the Guys and St Thomas NHS trust website, with further expertise in infection prevention and control.Professor Nicholas Hart is the director of the Lane Fox Respiratory Service at the Guys and St Thomas trust, and a professor of respiratory and critical care medicine at Kings College London.He has expertise in rehabilitation and home mechanical ventilation with chronic respiratory failure, according to his profile.The NHS in London said: We are proud of the tributes made by Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Carrie Symonds to the dedicated staff in Londons NHS.We wish the family all the best.It comes after a nurse thanked for helping to save Boris Johnsons le revealed things could have gone either way.The coronavirus-hit Prime Minister said Jenny McGee, , and Luis Pitarma, , watched over him for  hours in intensive care, giving him vital oxygen.He thanked the unconquerable medics at London’s St Thomas’ Hos­pital in an emotional video message after he was released from hospital following a seven-day battle with the killer bug.The PM said: “The NHS saved my le. No question. Things could have gone either way.”And thanks to the work from the doctors and nurses, the PM was able to be by Carries side for the birth - which came several weeks early.But he was quick toto work amid the coronavirus crisis - promising the nation he would outline the blueprints for how we will be released from the lockdown next week.No  previously said the baby was due in early summer, with further reports suggesting the end of May or beginning of June, meaning the couple conceived shortly after moving into Downing Street last year.It was confirmed that Boris will take his paternity leave later in the year, so he can still keep a firm grip on the countrys coronavirus crisis.While the new arrival is Ms Symonds first child, it is Mr Johnsons sixth - and his third son.He has four children with ex-we Marina Wheeler - two sons Milo, , and Theodore, , and two daughters Lara, , and Cassia, .Boris also has another daughter, Stephanie, born in , after an affair with art consultant Helen Macintyre.A spokesman for the couple said: The Prime Minister and Ms Symonds are thrilled to announce the birth of a healthy baby boy at a London hospital earlier this morning. Both mother and baby are doing very well.The PM and Ms Symonds would like to thank the fantastic NHS maternity team.The couple, who have been dating since he split from his we Marina back in , were engaged earlier this year and announced they were expecting back in February.The MP married barrister Marina Wheeler in  when she was pregnant with their daughter.Lara, who styles herself with the double barrelled surname Johnson-Wheeler, is a writer, editor and broadcaster. Milo JohnsonThe -year-old is the second eldest of the Johnson clan and is the oldest of his boys.He was educated at the £, a year Westminster School where he was said to excel at sports.In a  issue of his school magazine he was called a delight to watch and was without doubt the player of the season for his football skills. Cassie JohnsonThe -year-old is the third of Johnsons children with Marina. She studied at the £, per year Highgate School in North London.Like her father she is a writer and during her time at the private school she was a student editor of their alumni magazine Cholmeleian.She did not speak publicly about her parents orce, unlike her sister Lara who branded Boris a b*****d. Theodore JohnsonThe -year-old is the youngest of Johnsons children with ex-we Marina.It is not known which school he attended but it is believed to be one in London as he was pictured outside their Islington home in a school unorm in .He went on to attend Cambridge University - whereas his dad went to their rival Oxford. StephanieHis kids have a younger half-sister, Stephanie, who was born in  - the product of an affair with art advisory Helen Macintyre.Stephanie is the second youngest of Johnsons children. At first, he denied paternity and wasnt named on the birth certicate.However, his relations were revealed after a  court battle in which he sought an injunction to prevent her existence being reported. Wilfred Lawrie NicholasBoris fiancee Carrie Symonds gave birth on May .Both mum, , and baby are doing very well after the birth at the University College Hospital. The newborn baby is the latest to be born to a serving prime minister.Downing Street has been home to a number of babies, with Tony Blair and David Cameron both adding to their broods while in Number .But that is a relatively recent trend, with a gap of more than a century before Cherie Blair gave birth to Downing Street tot Leo Blair in .The whirlwind birth comes after a busy few months for the PM.After Decembers election and passing Brexit on January , he quickly found himself dealing with the coronavirus pandemic in early March.By April , he had contracted the deadly bug himself and ended up in hospital - spending three days in intensive care.He finally ed to work on Monday - but now faces more sleepless nights as he welcomes the new bundle of joy.Boris dad Stanley Johnson said  he was absolutely delighted” and “thrilled” with the news of another grandson.And politicians from across the spectrum have sent their best wishes to the happy couple.Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said the new arrival was fantastic news in challenging times.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david blunkett lockdown decisions government must make
story: Substitute the word politics for socialism and it is immediately obvious that prioritising in the coronavirus crisis poses almost impossible choices for the leadership of our country in moving to recovery.Recovery not just for our economy, but also for our social well-being and the normalisation of everyday le which makes living worthwhile.This week Boris Johnson promised that in the coming days he would set out a menu of options for a phasedto some form of normality in the weeks ahead.But the balance between lting the lockdown too quickly and failing to appreciate the long-term detrimental impact on every aspect of our lives, of the delay in ing to near normality, requires the wisdom of Solomon.Almost  years ago, when I became Home Secretary, Islamist terrorists launched their attack on the World Trade Center in New York.Almost , people lost their lives in one day and the immediate expectation was that there would be an attack here in the UK, most probably in London.When we met as a Cabinet, decisions had to be taken immediately as to whether to lock down the capital in the anticipation that lives might be lost in the days ahead.Steady nerves prevailed as we realised that the damage we would do to ourselves would be far greater than that which might be inflicted by our enemies.That is why, with our hearts in our mouths, we encouraged people to go to work and continue their lives as normal while taking every possible step behind the scenes to put in measures to protect us from attack.The virus is very dferent and the choices to be made are more dficult.Distancing and social isolation were clearly the right measure to put in place six weeks ago to reduce the transmission of infection, the pressure on the NHS and, above all, the loss of le.Whether or not the organised supply of PPE and the rapid expansion of testing was a failure of government is for another day — but what isn’t is the careful steps needed to get us out of this lockdown.Because while opinion polling shows not only public support for caution, but also anxiety about ing to work and social contact, the potential irreparable damage to our economy will hurt all of us.The job of politicians is to hear but then to balance alternative conclusions from the experts — as Winston Churchill put it: “Scientists should be on tap, but not on top.”In our democracy, leaders need to gain consent but they also have to assess and take risks. If the current measures start to erode, unforeseen dangers could arise.Yet, move too quickly and you risk being blamed for getting it wrong.In some form continuing to isolate without isolation will be necessary, but avoiding great damage to the most disadvantaged children, many of whom are receiving no schooling at all, is vital for our future.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Equally, preventing the potential shortening of the lives of older people through continuing inactivity and lack of social contact must form part of the equation.In the end it isn’t those appearing on TV and radio, often with contradictory analysis and advice, but elected politicians who must do the right thing.Carefully, conscientiously but bravely they must now lead us out of the unsustainable lockdown which, while necessary at the time, could,prolonged, be a more damaging medicine than the original disease.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus women equal leadership
story: AS I have often pointed out, there are many reasons why women make good leaders.In my experience, they tend to be good collaborators because their ego is unlikely to interfere with letting other people have good ideas, and be able to voice them and take credit for them.Their emotional intelligence and empathy makes them excellent communicators.But it’s not just my view that women are good leaders. Many studies show women are more focused on building community and teams.They are more likely than men to cultivate a erse set of advisers to help them succeed. They are also more likely to follow advice.A study by management consulting firm McKinsey found that women are more people- orientated and spend more time developing and coaching other leaders in their organisation. In other words, they don’t need to reserve all the glory for themselves.There is something  at play too, though. Female leaders are more likely to be blameddecisions are unpopular or ineffective. They are questioned and second-guessed more often than men.But then Covid- entered the equation and presented world leaders with a new challenge — an invisible enemy that is highly contagious, unpredictable and deadly.This pandemic has been an unprecedented test for all concerned.And guess what  A disproportionate number of those who have passed this test — countries such as Germany, New Zealand, Iceland and Finland — have women at the helm.It is not exclusively female-led countries that are doing well, of course. But bearing in mind only seven per cent of all world leaders are women, about  per cent of countries led by women are doing well when it comes to containing Covid-. Global health experts have concluded that one thing that has led to success in tackling coronavirus is — speed.Prof Tom Bollyky, director of global health programme at US think-tank the Council on Foreign Relations, said: “Countries that have not dithered in their response, that have mobilised quickly, have done well.”New Zealand’s PM Jacinda Ardern put it simply: “Go hard and go early.”The number of Covid--related deaths is predicted to be substantially lower in areas where leaders acted sooner, even by a week, because they flattened the curve and prevented new cases.Many women acted first and made the brave decision to shut down le as we knew it, even though that was an unpopular thing to do.But it seems women leaders are listening to World Health Organisation advice and also looking at other countries for guidance.They don’t think they have all the answers but women are able to put their ego to one side and let experts guide them — something which cannot be said of Donald Trump.Incidentally, I have not seen any women leaders making unfounded or dangerous suggestions about possible cures. Can you imagine a woman leader suggesting that people inject Dettol into themselves, as dingbat Trump recently suggested Or can you imagine a woman suggesting to people that they can fight coronavirus and winthey are strong enough This pandemic is not a battle to be fought and won. It is a virus, which can affect literally anyone.No one knows how they will be affected and that bullish “fight it” approach is, in my experience, very male. Conversely, the decision to protect everyone, putting the most at risk first, is more female.It’s interesting that some male leaders seem more interested in covering up the problems. Like Donald Trump, who thinks he is an expert on everything and more fixated on garnering praise for what he has done than fixing and getting right what has not gone so well.I know I am talking in generalisations here but my experience of women is that we want to understand the mistakes and fix them, not cover them up.This pandemic has been full of dficulty and tragedy for everyone.But perhaps one good thing that will come out of it is that the world will acknowledge women deserve an equal  when it comes to leadership.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.FORMER Love Islander Montana Brown this week posted some “Instagram vs reality” pictures ­– one of her in a lacy bralette and silky shorts, the other in a cute pink PJ set.But I couldn’t help but notice that she is wearing  eyelashes and full make-up in bed – in both sets.The very idea of wearing make-up, let alone  eyelashes at the moment, is unimaginable – especially to go to sleep.A far more realistic picture of my le at present, in fact, is that I am mainly wearing pyjamas all day as well as in bed.HAS anyone  been watching Madonna’s “Quarantine Diaries” on Instagram This week she said she has coronavirus antibodies, having been tested for the virus.And her conclusion in the face of this discovery  “Tomorrow, I’m going to go for a long drive in a car and I’m going to roll down the window, and I’m going to breathe in the Covid- air,” she says.Sorry, but what  No one knows yet whether it’s possible to have coronavirus more than once and the presence of antibodies may not provide protection against the disease.This seems like a risk no one should be advocating.The bonny baby, who has already inherited his father’s hair, was named after both their grandfathers and the doctor who saved Boris’s le.A wonderful and touching gesture.Wilfred, a name not popular since the s, takes its roots from “will” and “peace”, two words very apt for these dficult times.HUGE congratulations to Gigi Hadid and Zayn Malik, who confirmed this week they are expecting a baby.I guess the lockdown baby boom has already started, which just proves that le goes on.What a beautul baby they will have.It’s great to have some good news amid the gloom.WHAT a month it’s been for Boris Johnson.For the past few weeks he has faced professional challenges far bigger than those he may have anticipated when he was first elected Prime Minister.Not only that, but he has also survived time in intensive care suffering from coronavirus. And now he is a father yet again at .I think it’s fair to say that this period will go down in his own personal history as perhaps some of the most memorable few weeks of his le.EVEN the most hardened climate change denier cannot fail to pause for thought at the before and after photos of the Solent.Aerial shots of this part of Britain’s coastline look more like pictures that have been taken in the Caribbean.The water is so blue and so clean that it looks positively tropical. In fact, it’s unrecognisable after just six weeks of lockdown.The images show how the usually murky waters of the UK coastline have been transformed, which must surely be due in part to a reduction in pollution since the coronavirus pandemic stopped leisure traffic on the Solent.But other astonishing photos from all over the world have surfaced recently too.Pollution-free images of landmarks in Delhi and Beijing, which are all too often seen shimmering under a haze of smog, are a real reminder of our role in creating pollution and also in reducing it.Imagineanother silver lining to this terrible pandemic was that we all began to understand the effects of our impact on the environment, and that we took the threat of climate change more seriously – and started to take responsibility for changing our ways.I AM as keen as the next person to regain my freedom, and for things to begin toto normal.But I cannot be the only one who gave a shudder at the thought of being allowed to choose a “bubble” of just ten family members as friends, as was hinted at by some.Can you even imagine the disputes, upsets and hurt feelings that would result all over the landyour chosen bubble had chosen another group to huddle with In fact, that rule would likely cause so much offence that we would only have ten friends left. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kfc delivery drivers ignore coronavirus social distancing
story: KFC has launched an investigation after delivery drivers ignored social distancing measures and packed together to pick up orders.  Pictures show workers gathered outside a newly opened restaurant in Filton, Bristol, despite the coronvairus rules.Hundreds of KFC restaurants have reopened across the UK to deliver food during the lockdown, with social distancing measures introduced in stores to keep staff and customers safe.They include keeping people two metres apart and involve a contactless handover of food.Pictures sent to Bristol Live, however, show delivery riders flouting the measures, bunched close together as they waited to pick up orders.A KFC spokesperson told Sun Online: “We’ve introduced new measures to make sure we’re reopening responsibly for both our team members and delivery drivers.These include stickers on the floor and clear signage to help delivery drivers follow social distancing guidance, as well as contactless handover of food.Its nice to see how much weve been missed - and we’re grateful to our teams for working hard to keep up with demand!We’re looking into what’s happened at our Filton restaurant and our delivery partners are following up with their drivers in the area to remind them of these new processes.”It is unclear who the delivery drivers worked for but a sticker on the Filton restaurant says Deliveroo is among them.A spokesperson for Deliveroo said: Our rider support team is in constant contact with riders about the importance of respecting social distancing, including strict guidance and standards to follow.This includes regular prompts within our rider app to remind riders of the importance of contact free delivery, social distancing and hand washing.We have made clear thata rider is found to not be abiding by these important public health measures - title: uk weather forecast britain balmy 17c sunshine
story: The balmy sunshine is expected to stick around on Sunday, reaching C across much of the country.After a week of drizzle and gloom in lockdown, the UK has basked in some light relief today.The low pressure which has dumped torrential rain on much of the country this week has been forecast to move across Europe.And as the UK spends its sixth weekend in lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic, weather conditions are expected to be much more settled thanks to building high pressure.According to The Met Office, the change will result in “dry, fine and settled weather” this weekend and particularly next week.Saturday was warm with a high of C felt by most of the country.Further dry, fine and settled weather is expected on Sunday, with potential for very light winds - however most places will enjoy “dry and decent weather.”SundayThe Met Office predict most of the country will see sunny intervals, however some rain could fall in northern and eastern parts of the nation.For most of the country, a high of C will be felt, and a low of C.Monday to WednesdayMainly dry, sunny spells developing, few showers in Eastern England on Monday. Mainly dry, sunny spells in most places, but heavy showers in SW Tuesday. Dry and sunny on Wednesday.On Sunday, cloudier conditions are expected in the south and southwest with perhaps some light rain or drizzle in the far southwest.Some parts of the east coast will feel more of a chill in the air.The high pressure will remain in charge for most of next week, meaning the warm sunny weather is here to stay for at least a few more days.The Met Office warns that while the weather change will tempt many across the country to spend their weekend outdoors, the UK must continue to adhere to the coronavirus lockdown.Simon Partridge encouraged people to enjoy the sunshine from their backyards, balconies and daily hour-long walks - though he did add that UV levels will be reasonably high over the weekend, so people must cover up accordingly.The high pressure build won’t last forever, and is expected to move on by the following weekend and bring with it more wet and miserable weather.Ministers will be hoping the resurgence of sunshine will not encourage Brits to venture outside of their homes and break lockdown rules as has been seen in the past few weeks.For the beginning of next week, the weather still appears to be setting with the occasional shower in Eastern England on Monday ad heavy showers in the southwest on Tuesday.Generally the UK will remain dry with some sunny spells, particularly on Wednesday.The sunshine comes after Britain experienced as much rain in a day as it did for the rest of April two days ago.The Met Office is now predicting settled, warmer weather for the beginning of the month, although we can still expect some showers, and itll be much cooler than last week.Aprils sunshine was caused by a high pressure system from the continent - but recently weve faced the opposite, with low pressure systems bringing in colder weather and lots of rain.

title: madeleine mccann parents haunted 13 years lockdown
story: Kate and Gerry McCann were due to mark the anniversary of their daughters disappearance with a prayer gathering on Sunday, but lockdown measures mean they will hold an online service instead.Sharing a message online, Kate and Gerry likened Maddie’s experience to victims hit by the Covid- crisis - fear, hurt and loneliness.They wrote: There will be many vulnerable people whose situation will have become even more precarious in the current lockdown conditions, with fear, worry and isolation - emotions that we dreaded Madeleine experiencing and which haunted us for a long time - and still do on occasions.Our thoughts and prayers are with all those suffering at this time.Heart doctor Gerry, , and ex GP turned medical worker Kate, , were forced to axe the annual service they hold in memory of Maddie for the first time this year.But are still urging local villagers and well-wishers to come together remotely to mark the poignant occasion.The family are due to share prayers and readings online as they spend the anniversary behind closed doors at their home in Rothley, Leics.Writing on the Find Maddie and Facebook Campaign websites, they said: It is now  years since we were last with Madeleine.Her th birthday is to follow in the next couple of weeks - the latter tangibly, painfully, bringing it home to us what we have missed and continue to miss as a family.“I dont think any of us could have predicted the situation we all find ourselves in currently.It shows how easy it is to become complacent with our lives and circumstances, albeit a totally normal and understandable, human characteristic.Alongside an iconic photo of Maddie, they wrote: We have been fortunate to spend more time together as a family since lockdown began, an enforced block to a usually frenetic le, a silver lining to this dark cloud.It has made us think about Madeleine even more, as she would have shared this period of special closeness with us too.”It comes as Scotland Yard vows to continue the search for Maddie with renewed funds expected to be approved by the Home Office.Kate and Gerry added: The investigation to find Madeleine remains open and continues, even though, in a way dferent to the ideal.We remain grateful for the ongoing efforts and commitment from all those involved in the search to find her and we hope and pray, as always, that our efforts will be fruitful.”Thanking those who have supported them, the McCann’s said: Thank you to everyone still offering their support and good wishes for Madeleine and ourselves.Such solidarity continues to strengthen us. Thank you.Please take care and please spare a thought or prayer for Madeleine and all missing children this weekend.Heres hoping that more normal, safe and happy times are close at hand.Three-year-old Maddie vanished from a holiday apartment in Portugal’s Praia da Luz on May , .She had been left sleeping alone with her younger twin siblings while her parents were dining in a nearby tapas restaurant with pals.Her family cling on to a glimmer of hope she could still be alive.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: british airways staff not laid off to sign zero hour contract
story: BRITISH Airways wants its entire workforce to sign up to new contracts which would allow them to lay-off staff without negotiation.Union leaders fear the “traumatised” workforce is being railroaded into accepting the equivalent of zero-hour deals which could be ripped-up in the event of turbulence in future.Details emerged last night as The Sun was leaked a breakdown of job-losses at British Airways - with  engineers among those getting the boot.Yesterday union chiefs submitted legal papers to the High Court to argue that BA’s bid to make , staff redundant is illegal.They say the -day consultation period should in fact be  days.Leaders blasted the airline for jettisoning staff when BA parent company IAG was sitting on £.billion in its coffers.Airline insiders said the mooted June  deadline is in fact the earliest a deal could be reached, with the likelihood being staff issues are resolved by December.Workers given the boot will be offered standard statutory redundancy plus three months wages.A BA insider said: “A negotiating process is under way. Everything is up for grabs. The airline is fighting for survival.”The Sun was shown BA’s predicted job loss breakdown - with , flight crew getting the boot.Also leaving BA are , from head office,  engineers,  contact centre staff, , Heathrow ground staff and  Gatwick ground staff.The projected job loss total is ,.BA was yesterday accused of “dirty tricks” and faced a furious backlash over controversial plans to axe staff after using taxpayer cash to furlough its workforce.Five MPs near Heathrow airport wrote an angry letter to BA boss Alex Cruz asking for an urgent meeting to explain himself.The letter, penned by Seema Malhotra, MP for Feltham  Heston, said: “We would urge you to work with unions and government to do everything possible to find a solution and mitigate job losses.“We would greatly appreciateyou could urgently meet with us to provide a briefing on steps you are taking to alleviate the immediate financial pressures and reduce the number of jobs which could be cut, the extent to which government schemes are assisting with the impact and the support you will be providing to those who lose their jobs.”The cross-party letter was signed by Ruth Cadbury, MP for Brentford and Isleworth, John McDonnell MP for Hayes and Harlington, Virendra Sharma MP for Ealing and Southall, and James Murray MP for Ealing North.Another - MP, Tory Andrew Grfiths representing Burton - wrote to constituents accusing BA of “dirty tricks” and a huge “over-reaction”.He said: “If I was a cynic I would speculate that BA has done this precisely in the hope that everyone lobbies their MP and that they got more government bail-out money as the result.”Unite yesterday told BA staff: “BA has availed itself of millions of pounds of taxpayers money, ostensibly to avoid making staff redundant.“But they have not honoured that commitment or the spirit for which it was intended.“In fact it would appear that BA has simply sought to take advantage of staff being furloughed and dismiss them in their absence.”The unions said BAs behaviour was “both legally and morally” wrong.Swathes of furious cabin crew yesterday boycotted an online chat with BA’s cabin crew boss Amy James.Pilots union Balpa said it was “hugely disappointed” with BA for its “opportunism”.In a scathing response to BA’s plans, Balpa said the airline was “in breach” of Covid emergency plans: “The main purpose of the government Job Retention Scheme is to avoid the need for any compulsory redundancies.”BA was accused by the pilots’ bosses of trying to “exploit” the coronavirus pandemic.The Sun told first how BA had furloughed around , staff amid the coronavirus shutdown.BA bosses plan to ditch its Worldwide, Eurofleet and Mixed cabin fleets to create a single new crew team at Heathrow, serving long-haul and short-haul flights.The Sun told yesterday how BA could stop all flights from the UK’s biggest airport Heathrow - and may decide never toto the second largest hub Gatwick.BA’s redundancy plans and talks with the union were put on hold when coronavirus struck, decimating the airline industry.Insiders said strike action could follow because “BA staff are traumatised and have nothing left to lose”.BA was contacted for comment.

title: chinas bat woman coronavirus doc denies claims
story: CHINAs “Bat Woman” coronavirus scientist has denied trying to defect with secret files.Virologist Shi Zhengli is one of the worlds top coronavirus researchers - and was reportedly silenced after she unravelled the Covid- gene.Rumours spread across social media over the last  hours claiming she and her family had escaped from China, bringing hundreds of confidential documents to the US embassy in Paris.But Shi, a renowned researcher of bat coronaviruses, has assured friends and family everything is OK.On Saturday, she wrote on Chinese messaging service, WeChat: Everything is all right for my family and me, dear friends!No matter how dficult things are, itshall never happen. Weve done nothing wrong.With strong belief in science, we will see the day when the clouds disperse and the sun shines.The Global Times, a nationalistic paper published with approval from the Chinese Communist Party, first reported on Shi’s statement.It was reported last month that Shi was called back to her high security lab in Wuhan at the end of last year after a mysterious new respiratory condition in the city was identied as a new form of coronavirus.Within three days she completed its gene sequencing, the Mail on Sunday wrote.Her team’s work was said to have revealed the virus was linked to horseshoe bats found more than , miles away in Yunnan, a region of southern China.Gao Yu, a Chinese journalist, said of Shi: “We learned later her institute finished gene-sequencing and related tests as early as January  but was muzzled.”Shis recent comments come after a bombshell spy dossier claimed China lied to the world about the coronavirus outbreak.A -page document, obtained by Australias Saturday , has laid the foundation for a case being created against China for its handling of the deadly disease.It discusses the countrys silencing of doctors who tried to speak out about the virus, as well as the destruction of evidence in laboratories and refusing to provide samples to scientists who were working on a vaccine.The dossier, from the Five Eyes intelligence agencies of title: dont go to pub after coronavirus lockdown
story: BRITS should avoid the pub once social distancing measures are lted, a top doc warned today.People across the country will be itching to get back to their local for a few pints with pals after lockdown is eased, Englands deputy chief medical officer acknowledged today.But Dr Jenny Harries warned would-be boozers to think twice, saying its not a good thing to do.She said being outside - where Covid- does not survive as long - is generally safe.But she warned mixing with friends and others outside your household in a small environment like a pub could be disastrous.She explained: If you go as a family unit and sit in one place and youve got the same exposure there that you would in your house at home, thats probably quite a safe environment.If you go with a whole load of friends that you havent seen from before the coronavirus lockdown, sit in a pub in a very small environment, lean well over each other on the table and stay there for some hours face-to-face, thats really not a good thing to do.The deputy chief medical officer also warned against stopping off at the pub on the way to outdoor activities.Dr Harries said: Dont go to the pub on the way is probably the one to reduce your risk, although I recognise that everybody is wanting to do that.The deputy chief medical officer’s comments mean pubs across the UK will likely remain shut for some time.Last week it was reported pubs could remain closed until Christmas in a devastating blow to the trade.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: parks country first stage easing coronavirus lockdown

title: kate middleton virtual visit parents
story: Kate, , cooed over newborns in a video call to parents and midwives coping with hospital births during the coronavirus crisis.The duchess, a mum-of-three, gushed over -hours-old baby boy Max on the call to Kingston Hospital’s Maternity Unit.She spent two days on a work placement at the hospital, in south London, last November.Speaking on video link due to coronavirus restrictions she joked with mum Rebecca Attwood and dad John Gill, of London.She said: “This is definitely a first, I think.”And added: “Well firstly, huge congratulations. Is it a little boy or a little girl ”Rebecca, who sat beside her son’s cot, said: “It’s a little boy.”Given a closer look at little Max, the Duchess said: “He is so sweet. Ah, congratulations! When did you have him ”Told he had arrived at pm the previous night, the future queen replied: “My goodness, you must be exhausted.”Rebecca replied: “Yep. I’m pretty tired now.”Midwives wearing PPE described how staff were coping with anxious mums facing going into labour during the pandemic.Jo Doumouchtsi, Perinatal Mental Health Midwe, said: “The main issues that women are having at the moment really are around coming into hospital and worries about catching Covid, but also about the isolation after the baby is born.“They have to self-isolate, so they are having limited support from their other family members.“We are finding that there’s women that have no mental health history that are actually becoming incredibly anxious because of the situation currently.“So we’re having a lot more referrals which are specically around anxiety to do with Covid.”A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.The duchess also held talks with midwives at the hospital over a zoom video call.She spoke about the need for NHS staff to get help they need as they deal with coronavirus.Kate said: “We’ve heard it with the frontline workers, for those who are struggling, they don’t feel they can reach out because they feel guilty for doing it, which is extraordinary to hear.“With new mums and parents and families, they don’t want to feel like they’re overburdening, but it is so important to reach out and ask for help when you do need it.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. whether it’s on the phone, through social media, in any form actually -you have got access to it, it does provide that normality and normalising of some of these anxieties and these worries.”Her virtual visit was held ahead of Maternal Mental Health Awareness Week starting tomorrow.The royal couple regularly visited the award-winning White Eagle in Rhoscolyn in Anglesey, North Wales, while William was stationed in the area working as a search and rescue helicopter pilot.During the three years he was based at RAF Valley, they would often tuck into a traditional pub lunch, with William opting for burger and chips and Kate ordering fish and salad.But it’s now been revealed the haunt has gone bust after suffering harsh losses due to coronavirus.Sarah O’Toole and Jason Bell of Grant Thornton UK have been appointed joint administrators of  venues, including the White Eagle.Sarah said: “We are hopeful we can find a buyer for the businesses despite the current challenges facing the pub and hospitality sector.During the couple’s time in Anglesey, a member of staff revealed: “They’re just like any other young couple in love – until you realise they’ve got armed bodyguards on the next table.Prince William drinks bitter, perhaps a pint or two, and Kate sticks to white wine and sparkling water.He seems to enjoy our home-made burgers and chips. Which  discovered jellies made with the ­thickening agent konjac – banned by the EU because it can cause choking. And the consumer group said two soft drinks, Fresca Original Citrus and Mountain Dew, were listed by the online giant that contain brominated vegetable oil which is outlawed.The oil is used to stop ingredients separating in the bottle but can cause headaches, memory loss, and impaired balance.The items were on Amazon Marketplace which offers goods from so-called secondary sellers, not Amazon itself – and all have since been removed. Which  has previously found banned and recalled toys for sale via Amazon. Amazon said: “If customers have concerns about an item, we encourage them to contact our customer service so we can take action.” Consumer watchdogs who found the products for sale claim Amazon is failing to protect customer safety. They have already criticised the Amazon Marketplace site for selling toys deemed unsafe under EU safety rules. Marketplace sales offer goods supplied by so-called secondary sellers - rather than Amazon itself. The world’s biggest retail site hosts their listings. Sue Davies, head of consumer protection at Which , said: “The Government must make their responsibility clear and ensure that unsafe products, including foods, are prevented from going on sale and swtly removedthey are found.” The Food Standards Agency said: “Everyone involved in online marketplace selling - from the host s to the seller - must ensure food is safe. We want these companies to take more responsibility for the products sold on their sites.”  All products have since been removed from the site. Amazon said: “Safety is important to us and we want customers to shop with confidence in our stores. We have proactive measures in place to prevent suspicious or non-compliant products from being listed and we monitor the products sold in our stores for product safety concerns.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPicking a baby name is no easy task as Kate Middleton found out when she was expecting her first child, Prince George. Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, , and husband Prince William, , decided not to find out the gender of their firstborn, whom would become third in line to the throne. Instead they had a list of potential names lined up depending on whether they welcomed a baby girl or boy. And although we know the couple went on to call their son George Alexander Louis, there was another boyaposs name Kate is said to have been particularly fond of. Royal expert Katie Nicholl previously revealed in Vanity Fair: “Courtiers insisted the pair had not found out the sex of their unborn baby, and friends close to the couple claim William wanted a surprise. “Although Kate apparently suspected it was a boy and had set her heart on the name Alexander, they had not yet decided what to call their firstborn.” Ms Nicholl continued: “Kate was reported to have affectionately referred to her bump as ‘our little grape’ while she was pregnant, and there was a flurry of betting on possible names.”  A friend of the couple also told the author: ”When I saw William a few weeks before the birth he said they didnapost know [the babyaposs gender] and didnapost want to find out. He said there are so few surprises in le — this was one he wanted to keep. “Kate said she thought it was a boy because the baby kicked so much. The couple eventually settled on George for their little boy, which hails back to the Queen’s father, King George VI. The Duke and Duchess did however retain Kate’s favourite name as one of George’s middle names.  The little prince is now affectionately known to pals by his nicknames, which include PG, or PG Tips, after his initials. Meanwhile, Kate admitted it ”slightly terrying” becoming a first-time mum in  and standing on the steps of the Lindo Wing hours after giving birth. As she clutched her new baby boy in her arms the clicking of dozens of photographers and their flashing cameras went off.  Speaking about Georgeaposs debut, she told Giovanna Fletcheraposs Happy Mum, Happy Baby podcast: [It was] slightly terrying, slightly terrying, Iaposm not going to lie. Everyone had been so supportive and both William and I were really conscious that this was something that everyone was excited about and, you know, weaposre hugely grateful for the support that the public had shown us. And actually for us to be able to share that joy and appreciation with the public, I felt was really important. But equally it was coupled with a newborn baby, and inexperienced parents, and the uncertainty of what that held, so there were all sorts of mixed emotions.  Asked what it was like holding her son for the first time, she said: Amazing, amazing. It is extraordinary as I’ve said. How can the human body do that  It is utterly extraordinary actually. And he was very sweet. And also sort of relieved that he was a happy, healthy boy.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs the UKaposs lockdown enters its seventh week, Boris Johnson has promised to share a roadmap for how some of the strictest measures will be gradually eased. At the Downing Street briefing on Thursday, the Prime Minister claimed Britain is past the peak of its coronavirus outbreak and that he will reveal a comprehensive plan on how the nation will get back to work and school next week. However preventing a second wave of deadly infections is vital and professor Chris Whitty, the chief medical officer, has warned that We are nowhere near the end of this epidemic. In order to keep the aposRapos - the number of people each Covid- patient infects - below one, any relaxing of restrictions will be gradual. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here  The details wonapost be confirmed until next week at the earliest, but initial reports have given ideas of what le after lockdown could involve. Below we look at some of the major changes that could be headed our way. Back to work by May  Brits couldto work on May  under the Prime Ministeraposs plan to ease lockdown measures. The Tuesday following the late May bank holiday has been highlighted as a possible date for offices, factories and some shops to re-open, according to the Sun. This would allow businesses to get ready to bring in new social distancing measures for workers, such as screens and spaces between desks, designed to prevent any further spread of coronavirus. However, the date could be pushed backthe number of infections has not fallen to a manageable level by this point, the newspaper claims. A Downing Street source told the paper last night that the exact timing is very much a live conversation. Two-metre rule relaxation  Government advice requiring people to stay two metres apart to prevent the spread of coronavirus is being reviewed, according to reports. The Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencieshas been asked to consider the evidence for asking people to stay so far away from each other, thestates. Although current advice in the UK is to remain two metres from other people, the World Health Organisation advises a lesser distance of one metre. The paper claims that the social distancing rule is now a topic of live discussion as ministers map out a plan to ease lockdown restrictions. Fever tests for commuters  It is understood that commuters may have to take their temperatures before boarding public transport when the coronavirus lockdown is eased. The Department for Transport and Public Health England are considering the measure to prevent the highly infectious virus from spreading on crowded trains when the UK begins toto work, The Times reports. Rail operators are also considering requiring passengers to book ahead for busy services, the paper adds, adding that to reduce overcrowding, commuters would reserve a -minute slot online before boarding. First-class carriages may also be scrapped with passengers no longer allowed to get off at some stations, the paper goes on to claim. Under the proposals anyone with a high temperature - a telltale symptom of Covid- - would be required to stay at home. Other measures which have been adopted by other countries include providing hand sanitiser, asking passengers to wear face masks and signs asking people not to use busy services. Premier league proposals  The Premier League has set a target date to restart the football season on June . If its proposals for Project Restart are approved by the government, games would take place behind closed doors so that the current season can be finished, the Sun reports. Clubs are hoping to restart training in mid-May. No timeframe has been given for when fans will be allowed to attend games again, but they will be banned until at least next season. Matches are likely to take place in a small number of stadiums, such as the Emirates in north London or Etihad in Manchester, with no clubs allowed to play in their home ground. Air travel Heathrow Airport boss John Holland-Kaye told PA it would be physically impossible to maintain social distancing measures at airports and that there will need to be better health checks of passengers. He said UK airports should follow countries in Asia which have introduced screening measures, temperature checks and improved hygiene procedures. Passengers may also be required to wear masks during flights. Mr Holland Kaye added: The constraint is not about how many people you can fit on a plane, it will be how many people you can get through an airport safely. Low cost airline WizzAir has resumed flights overseas from Luton Airport - but British Airways is culling , jobs and Ryanair , as other airlines struggle with the impact of the crisis. Rail travel The Rail Delivery Group is coordinating the rail industryaposs response to the pandemic. It said services will continue to run on a reduced timetable and passengers will be given clear advice about how to stay two metres apart. Changes to travel will be made following the Governmentaposs advice and train companies will remind customers of the action they need to take while using their services.  Great Western Railway has said it is looking to increase services from mid-May, with further increases when the Government starts to ease the lockdown. Elsewhere, the Rail, Maritime and Transportunion warned there was zero chance of increasing transport services soon, amid speculation of a rise in journeys on May  or May  when a new rail timetable is due. Industry sources said last week no dates have yet been agreed or announced. More working from home Many companies are set to keep in place changes they have made to deal with the coronavirus crisis, such as staff working from home, a new study suggests. Research by the Institute of Directorsindicated there will also be a greater focus on digital services when the current lockdown ends. Businesses have been innovating in response to the lockdown, with almost one in six of  firms polled reporting they had launched a new product or service, usually involving hand gel or protective equipment. Property services provider CBRE has said British firms should look to Asia as a guide on how offices might approach reopening in the future. It advises against a full throttleto work, with social-distancing measures needing to be reduced gradually and in line with public health guidance. Pubs and restaurants Major takeaway chains such as KFC, Burger King and Pret A Manger started reopening a few branches this week. They have introduced strict safety and social distancing measures including regular handwashing and sanitising every  minutes. There are also restrictions on the amount of customers allowed in a store at the same time.  Costa Coffee is reopening some branches - only for delivery or drive-thru - and has put in place measures to protect staff and customers - such as new social distancing guidelines, enhanced hygiene procedures and personal protective equipment for team members. Meanwhile, pubs are braced for large numbers of people eager to visit their locals when they reopen again.Wetherspoons boss Tim Martin this week voiced an intention to reopen the chain in or around June.But decreased turnover from having far fewer tables to adhere to social distancing may make opening some bars and restaurants unviable. Shopping In the coming weeks, some non-essential businesses will be allowed to open, it is believed. This includes garden centres and car showrooms, provided social distancing can be maintained. Lobby group the British Retail Consortium has guidelines on ensuring the safe reopening of non-essential firms. Suggestions include limiting entry and exit points, using floor markings to outline social distancing and keeping changing rooms closed.  The guidance also suggests installing cleaning stations with hand sanitiser and disinfectant wipes at the front of stores. Contactless payments would be encouraged and self-checkout stations cleaned regularly. Staff who serve customers are to be protected with screens, visors and gloves. Other measures may include one-way systems through stores, a cap on how many people are allowed in at any given time and security guards at the door.

What they didn’t know is that they’d both strike a chord with each other’s partners. Both couples then split up before the newly-single partners got together in a karaoke love swap. Heather Whiteley, , had been with Darren Smith, , for two years before they went along to the event at their local bowls club.Heather said: “I met Darren through Facebook. He was sweet, understanding and easy to talk to.“We were always up for a laugh so when we saw there was a karaoke evening being held at the bowls club, we agreed to go together. “I love a bit of karaoke and it sounded like fun.” While there they got talking to another couple – Peter Brettell, , and Susie Spencer, . Heather said: “We kind of knew Peter and Susie through the local community anyway. “They were involved in running a few karaoke nights and events locally. We had a great time that night, enjoying a sing-song and a few drinks together.” From that meeting in February last year, the two couples became friends, meeting a few times a week for a drink or a singalong session. Heather said: “We added each other on Facebook too and would chat on there. Susie and Peter seemed like a great couple. We weren’t super close, but we all got on well. “But in time, my relationship with Darren hit the rocks. We’d been ­having problems for some time but it took us a while to admit it.  “We were arguing all the time and eventually, in May , we split. “It was a really sad, dficult time, and I was still reeling from the break-up when I found out that Peter and Susie had ended their own relationship, too.” With both couples having split, Heather reached out to Susie’s former partner Peter. “I thought he might need someone to talk to,” she said. It turned out Heather had hit the right note.  “Peter wasn’t the type to talk about his feelings but he admitted he was ­struggling after his split from Susie.“And, as we got ­chatting, it ­became apparent wehad more in ­common than we thought.“We confided in each other. We realised we were the only ones who truly understood what we were both going through.” The pair became a shoulder for each other to cry on and soon began spending more time together. Peter said: “Susie and I had been together for two years but we were arguing a lot before we broke up. We just weren’t a team any more. “Darren knew Susie’s family through the karaoke nights. “We weren’t really close with Darren and Heather but we saw them in the pub quite often and would also chat on Facebook. “When all this happened, I turned to Heather for support.  “I don’t have many friends I can talk to about emotional stuff so when Heather asked meI wanted to talk, I opened up and it went from there. “She really listened to what I had to say and I wasn’t used to that. I felt I hadn’t been able to talk to Susie properly for months.” Heather added: “In time, Peter and I started to get close. I started to feel butterflies in my stomach for the first time in years. “It wasn’t long before we became a couple.”  Love Both pairs have since found lasting love after the karaoke carry-on. Darren and Susie are still together and Heather, who works as a home carer, and Peter, an events organiser, got engaged in September.  Heather, who lives in Winterton, near Scunthorpe, said: “It’s been a bit of a roller coaster but I don’t regret a thing because it led me to Peter, my true love.” And Peter added: “Heather and I got together around the same time as Darren and Susie. It was fast, but it felt right. “It was odd that we ended up ­together and so did they but, to be honest, they are welcome to each other because we are happier than ever.”

title: great big lockdown survey tell
story: NewsGreat Big Lockdown Survey: Tell us what le is like for you and your familyWe want to know your experiences of this period, so that we can paint a detailed picture of the extraordinary times we are living throughShareCommentsByJen Williams:,  APR Updated:,  MAY NewsA unique nationwide survey has been launched capturing what British le is really like in the coronavirus lockdown. The Great Big Lockdown Survey, launched by the Daily Mirror and other news media, will paint a detailed picture of the extraordinary times we are living through. Britain has never before dealt with a crisis of this nature, a global health emergency that has sent shockwaves through our way of le, our outlook and our economy. So the Great Big Lockdown Survey poses an array of questions about your hopes and fears during the pandemic, your sense of how it is being handled, how your le has changed since the outbreak and how you think it might change on the other side. Have your say by taking part in the survey If you’re unable to see the survey above, click here That includes the impact on your finances, mental health and general wellbeing, but also how your habits and priorities may have altered - possibly, in some respects, forever. From struggling to keep a business afloat to the experience of redundancy or furlough, from applying for benefits to accessing food and advice, from the effect on your children to your work-le balance, cooking habits and entertainment under lockdown, we aim to provide a snapshot of an unprecedented era. We want to know about the true impact of isolation, but also whether the crisis has brought communities closer together, as people have come to rely more on the kindness of friends and neighbours.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA newborn received a royal welcome when the Duchess of Cambridge paid a virtual ­visit over the internet. Kate, who has a keen ­interest in early years development, spoke to parents Rebecca Atwood and John Gill about what it was like to have a baby during the lockdown. The Duchess, , cooed at baby Max, who was just  hours old, and said: “Hello! Very nice to meet you! This is ­definitely a first, I think!” After sending “huge congratulations” to his parents, Kate added: “He is so sweet. When did you have him ” When told he had arrived at pm the previous night, she replied: “My goodness, you must be exhausted! Kate’s surprise ‘bedside visit’ came during a call to staff at Kingston Hospital’s Maternity Unit on April . She did a two-day work placement at the south west London hospital last November, and this time heard from staff about their experiences during the pandemic. Six midwives took it in turns to join the chat, while one pulled on personal protective equipment and took a ­laptop to introduce mum-of-three Kate to baby Max and his parents. The Duchess dialled in from Anmer Hall in Norfolk – where the Cambridges have been staying during the lockdown – and heard that the hospital had dealt with a rise in referrals for anxiety. Jo Doumouchtsi, perinatal mental health midwe, said: “The main issues women are having are around coming into hospital and catching Covid, but also about the isolation after the baby is born.  “They have to self-isolate, so they are having limited support from their other family members.” And midwe Jenner Tshibamba added: “We want women to know we’re here, we’re still open. “Even with what’s ­going on, we’re here to listen to you, we’re still here to make sure we provide you with the best care for your pregnancy, for your baby and support your family.”  The hospital’s perinatal mental health team – which includes psychiatrists and mental health nurses – sends out a weekly newsletter that gives mums advice for coping during the pandemic and lists what ­services are available. Kate said: “That’s probably such a valuable tool for them now. To you all there, you do an amazing job, ­honestly, as you say, ­babies come all the time. “The fact you’re having to work in these dficult times… well done.”  Kate told the midwives how she and husband William had spoken to NHS staff about the importance of reaching outthey were feeling low. She said: “They don’t feel they can reach out because they feel guilty for doing it, which is extraordinary. “With new mums and parents and families, they don’t want to feel like they’re overburdening but it is so ­important to reach out and ask for help when you do need it.” As part of their work to support people during the pandemic, the Duke and Duchess have created a new text service dedicated to key workers.  Leading mental health charities will work together to provide -hour ­support to those under pressure while millions of us stay at home to save lives. Mind, Samaritans, Shout, Hospice UK and the Cambridges’ Royal Foundation will provide support and online resources to the key workers keeping Britain ­moving through the crisis. William, , said the text service would be their “top priority” in the coming months. And ahead of Maternal Mental Health Awareness Week – which starts tomorrow – Kate said new mums should also speak upthey need help. Typically, around one in  women experience a mental illness during ­pregnancy or in the first year after giving birth. Kate said that in her experience, talking to other mums helped.  She said: “You realise you are going through the same thing. Before that, you’re worried that actually, what you’re experiencing, you’re the only one going through it. “To be able to share it in whatever way, whether it’s on the phone, through social media – in any form – ­it does ­normalise some of these anxieties.” Using a video call to ­connect with others was exactly what Princess Charlotte did on her fth birthday on Saturday. Kate and William threw a party for their daughter at home, with lots of fun and games for her and brothers, George, six and Louis, two.

title: long queues after rubbish tips
story: NewsHuge queues form at rubbish tips reopening for first time since lockdown startedWaste facilities in Manchester opened for the first time in weeks today while across the UK there has been a surge in flytipping since the lockdown was put in place on March ShareCommentsByEdward DracottEleanor BarlowAine Fox:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsLong queues outside a tidy tip in Bolton this morning " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHuge queues have built up as tidy tips reopen for the first time in weeks - despite warnings that le is not ing to normal. The facilities in Manchester were open for the first time since the start of lockdown today, with social distancing measures put in place. It follows a surge in flytipping since Brits were told they must stay at home. Local Government Secretary Robert Jenrick has said councils should be confident to reopen tips as soon as possible - although there have been warnings that protective equipment for waste workers needs to be provided. At the waste centre on Reliance Street in Manchester a queue of cars was already waiting by .am, half an hour before it was scheduled to open. On Saturday only vehicles with number plates ending in even numbers were allowed in, as part of a system to control the number of visitors, meaning some people were turned away. Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham said: While we are reopening centres, this is not ato normal. We would ask the public to limit their journeys and only travel to a household waste and recycling centreit is absolutely essential to do so.  Centres are only accepting bagged general waste and Greater Manchester residents need to show proof of address to use the sites, which are limiting the number of cars allowed in. Mr Jenrick said reopening tips in a staged manner was sensible and the right thing to do. He said: The longer we delay it, the longer those queues are going to be when the waste sites reopen. He said visiting a tip is a perfectly legal thing for people to do, but warned people obviously donapost abuse it.  The minister added: There is no reason why you cannot travel to a tip to put household waste there or do recycling. Councils should have the confidence to reopen them as soon as possible. Councillor David Renard, environment spokesman for the Local Government Associationsaid police would be needed to manage inevitable traffic queues at tips.  He said: HWRCscan only reopen when they have sufficient staffing and social distancing measures are in place to protect staff and members of the public, which remains paramount. To safely manage visitor flow and pent-up demand, the police will need to manage inevitable traffic queues at the sites, with consideration needing to be given to whether supportive measures, such as a permit system and longer opening hours might be needed.  He said it is crucial that staff are given PPE and said re-openings will be decided locally based on risk assessments taken in each local authority area. New research this week showed fly-tipping had increased by % in rural communities during the lockdown. Researchers from the universities of Southampton and Portsmouth said the increase in illegal waste dumping followed the closure of almost all tips, while at the same time the number of DIY projects has increased by householders stuck at home.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe teenage son of a doctor who died after pleading for PPE last night demanded an apology from Health Secretary Matt Hancock. Dr Abdul Mabud Chowdhury, , warned the government about the lack of personal protective equipmentfor NHS staff.The consultant urologist is one of more than  NHS and social care workers to die after contracting coronavirus.Today, in an open letter shared with the Sunday Mirror, his heartbroken son Intisar, , called on the health secretary to acknowledge his mistakes. He told the under-fire minister: “Do not let my father’s death be in vain.” Intisar, whose dad worked at Homerton hospital in Hackney, east London, also backed the Sunday Mirror’s campaign to reward our healthcare heroes. We are calling for a special daily allowance to be paid immediately to nurses, doctors, support staff and care workers who are putting their lives on the line. Intisar added: “Nurses, doctors, care workers and so many others put their lives on the line every day to save the British public. “My father would be proud to support the campaign for a special daily allowance.” Open letter to Matt Hancock in full Dear Matt Hancock, My father, Dr Abdul Mabud Chowdhury, was an NHS hero who gave his le for this country. He saw at first hand the shortages of PPE for workers treating coronavirus patients. While my father was unwell, he wrote an open letter to the Prime Minister appealing for more PPE. His request went ignored and two weeks later he passed away. He was only .  Today, I write an open letter to you in the hope that you might learn from my father’s tragic death. My family cannot rule out that a lack of PPE caused my father’s death. For many other frontline workers, the relationship between inadequate protection and death is even more evident. Yet in , you were warned that the NHS would be overwhelmeda pandemic hit. Exercise Cygnus was the government’s opportunity to prepare for the global crisis we see today. While PPE does expire, making it more dficult to stockpile, why did you wait for the death toll to rise before taking action  Having never worked as a medical professional yourself, you also had no right to imply NHS workers had misused PPE. There is a shortage of PPE – it is not being overused. To say otherwise shows complete disrespect to my father’s death.  Other workers in hospitals, such as cleaners and technicians, also require protection. As do staff in care homes. What are you doing to ensure that they cansafely to their families at night  I am not expecting perfection, but I do expect that your mistakes are admitted and learned from. I ask you again to acknowledge the Government’s errors in responding to the virus and become a leading example by being the first to hold yourself accountable. I have no political affiliation and this is not a political attack. This is a human rights crisis.

title: mums cunning plan kate middleton
story: NewsMums cunning plan to get Kate Middleton to wear her necklace changed her le foreverWhen a husband and we sent Pippa Middleton a necklace to gt to Kate for Prince Georges birth, they were hardly to know what was around the corner for themShareCommentsByEmma Jones:,  MAY NewsBeatrice and Arnaud de Montille " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailArnaud de Montille and his we Beatrice started making jewellery at home. When it became a go-to shop for the Royal Family, they ended up with a worldwide business and a special invitation. In their own words, they tell their story... One day my we Beatrice went to a little shop on our high street that does personalised presents. They didn’t have what she wanted, so the next day, when she decided to have a go at making it herself, our lives changed for ever. Born in France, we moved to London in . We were struggling to manage the work-le balance as I was in banking, a heavy-going job, and Beatrice had just had our second child. She wanted to go part-time in her office job, but the company refused. She was considering a career change, so when she made her first necklace, it got her thinking. The day after that trip to the high street, she ordered a gold charm and chain from the internet as well as a handheld ‘graver’ . By the end of the day she’d engraved the necklace with the names of our children and was proudly wearing it. Initially, it was a bit of a hobby. She sat at the kitchen table and began engraving pieces to sell at Christmas fairs and local events. Word of mouth spread in the village and soon she was making jewellery for friends, family and anyone who needed something special to mark an occasion. We decided to set up a website for her creations rather than open a shop and, after a few weeks, her orders slowly grew. She’d started buying the charms and chains and engraving them herself, but once we went online as a unique company, called Merci Maman, she had to design and make the charms herself. I used to help out in evenings and at the weekends and knew we were on to a good thing. It was a slow, old-fashioned process though, and we did it all by hand. As orders grew, we hired a few people to help and, in , I left my job to join the company. At this point we had seven people working for us and opened a small office a stone’s throw from our house. I too saw the benefits of this kind of work. We had four kids by then and I could take them to school and be home for supper, which was a whole new world for me. I was determined for Merci Maman to be a success. Our USP became the personalisation angle. You can have absolutely anything. Children’s names, love notes, GPS coordinates of where people met or live, you name it, we can do it. We were published in a few magazines and Pippa Middleton ended up buying something from us for a friend. She was so pleased with it, she sent us a thank you letter afterwards! She went on to buy a few more pieces from us for presents. We were thrilled, and it got us thinking of our dream customers.  When Kate Middleton was pregnant with her first child in  my we and I both said, ‘Wow, imagineshe had a necklace with the name of the future prince or princess on it ’. She is an icon across the whole world and an inspiration to so many women. So, when George was born, we made her a necklace with his name on and a little ‘W’ charm on it also for William. We sent it to Pippa so she could gt it to her sister from herself. Well, you can imagine how we felt when we saw a picture of Kate wearing it. The excitement was sky high! Sure enough, all over the newspapers were pictures of Kate wearing the necklace we’d made for her. What happened next was a big article about Kate’s jewellery, which went viral. And there was our necklace. The effect was instant. We had , hits on the website in three days – equivalent to all of the traffic we normally get in December, our busiest month. We had to focus on production, getting stock in and we had to recruit to cope. It was very demanding, but extremely exciting!  We had to act fast to get the staff so we could meet the demands of the orders and within weeks we’d expanded to a team of . The necklace had created a buzz worldwide so we had to start shipping all over the world and make sure some of our staff were bilingual so we could translate the website into dferent languages. What followed was three offices – in London, Paris and Berlin – to make sure we could reach everyone. Business went insane and six months on we were a dferent company in terms of figures. We even gained a few more royal customers. Mike Tindall has bought a few pieces for his we, the Queen’s granddaughter Zara, and whenever Royals order they use the website, just like normal customers. After , we had such a huge burst internationally that we applied for The Queens Award, which is an honour awarded to a few select UK businesses every year. We won for our contribution to exports and my we and I were invited to Buckingham Palace. After mingling with the guests someone asked us to head to a private room with them. We followed and there sat the Queen, who wanted to have a private chat with us. We were in the room for quite a long time and she asked us all sorts of questions. When we’d moved to England, how the business started. She was interested in all the ins and outs! She didn’t even realise Kate had a necklace when we told her. It was amazing and I’ll never forget it.  An hour later we were drinking champagne in the Palace and a lady came up to us and said, ‘Oh you’re the French couple who set up the jewellery company – the Queen told me all about you!’ She had remembered all the details. Even that we have four children. It was incredible how she absorbed the information. It’s  years since the company started and we now do rings, bracelets, earrings, accessories and a full men’s range. Working with my we has been great – Beatrice is good at the designing side of things, and I stick to e-commerce. Plus we parent together well as we split work and family time evenly. The kids are between seven and  so they’re too young to get involved, but they do love to help us package up parcels and to go on set at photoshoots. The necklace Kate has is called the Duchess and it’s the same price it always was, £. It’s important for us it’s affordable for everyone. We also practise our work-le balance ethos. Everyone who works for us can create their own schedule to make sure they have enough family time.

story: NewsNurses moving letter to those with loved-ones in hospital with coronavirusRebecca Heseltine who works on the acute medical unit at St George’s Hospital, Tooting, has seen six die in a single day and has to regularly stop distraught visitors seeing sick relativesShareCommentsByAmy Sharpe:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsRebecca Heseltine has dealt with distraught families " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A nurse has written a moving letter to those with loved ones ­hospitalised due to coronavirus.She tells them: “We gave up the luxury of social distancing so we can hold their hands.” Rebecca Heseltine, , who works on the acute medical unit at St George’s Hospital, Tooting, South London, has seen six die in a single day on her -bed ward and has to regularly bar distraught visitors from seeing sick relatives. She said: “We are seeing fast deterioration and deaths with tiny windows for relatives to say goodbye, or not at all. I wrote this hoping it would resonate with someone.” Rebeccaaposs letter in full To you. Please know that we remember you. Know that we are thinking of you. Know that we don’t mind, and that you aren’t bothering us when you ring four times a sht to find out how your sick loved one is. Know that we are caring for your mum, dad, brother, sister or friend just a little harder right now. We gave up the luxury of social distancing so we can stand close and hold their hands. Know that we have been known to stretch our old, wired-to-the- wall phones across bays so they can speak to you, and that we would move heaven and earth to put you at ease just by hearing their voice. Know that calling you with bad news is something that we will never get used to. Know that even contemplating shattering someone’s world via telephone makes our stomachs churn in a way that we have never felt before, and that nothing will ever make that feel right.  You must know that we stay with them until you get there. If you can get there, that is. Butyou can’t, know that we are there to hold the ward iPad up with stinging, tear-filled eyes as you try to find the words to say goodbye. Know that we do every single possible thing to make sure that they are comfortable, and that they know that they are loved, and will never be alone. We know how daunting it must be to have to put on full PPE and gingerly stand next to a very sick and very scared person. We know what it’s like to cry with a mask on. We know that trying to do that in the allotted  minutes you are allocated will probably be the most dficult thing you will ever do.
