title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. title: future-shock-the-question-is-not-whether-ufos-are-real-its-why-the-us-military-have-only-now-admitted-their-existence
story: Still, perhapsits what we deserve for feedingat the charred teatsof ourlying, propagandistic, state-influencedmasters to fill the minds of the weak with fluff and lies. But youre not fooled. Youre smart. You see though it all and enjoy the sport of picking it all apart,exposing our dark filthmongeringto the purying light of social media through the righteous filter of yourownpersonal perception of truth. Good for you.Yet, even now,some global media stalwarts remainuntouchable, some undefinablemoxie elevatingthemabove even the mostpolarised and paranoid of the hate-fuelled rabble - and withinthis ever-contracting circle, SirTrevor McDonald remainsa journalisteveryone trusts. Its always beenhis unique selling point ndash natural authority crystallised by a rich vocal timbre oozing gravitas and empathy. Then therersquos that fine moustache ndash a symbol of old-school chivalry, curled snugly around his tunnel of truth like a greying cat warmed by the hot breath of righteousness.If Trevor ever approached you in the city centre, perhaps clad inurine-stained jogging bottoms and uttering a torrentof wordsuncomfortable in its over-familiarity with internalisedchaos, maybe asking for change towards his train fare home, then you still wouldnrsquot hesitate to dig deep ndash evenhanding over yoursmart phone so he could check the stationtimetable online. Trust is everything.Thatrsquos why I believed this establishment-approved Knight of the Realm when he said something so outre thatit came from anyone it wouldhave signalled the end of their tellycareer -UFOs were real. The year was  ndash the fag end of true reality, a few years before the mass fractionalisation, isolationism and grotesque self-glorication bequeathed to us by the digital dawn. No phones, no internet, your gran could whistle the Top Ten and  million folk watched Coronation Street. Before the internet,Ken Barlowrsquos bed-hopping was all teenagers had to learn about sex.This vacuum of yawning nothingness allowed for mass pop culture crazes that infected entire continents with short-lived delirium ndash and in , the brow of the globersquos collective consciousness was hot and sweaty with X-Files fever.In fact, so seismic was the showrsquos influence that ITV saw fit to dedicate an entire eveningrsquos scheduling to UFOs ndash showcased somewhat predictably in the familiar format of a  debate. Nothing that would scare the horses, then ndash or elderly folk too jiggered to get up and change the channel after Corrie.Saucers full of secretsIT was as a prelude to this peculiar pow-wow that host Sir Trevor greeted viewers with an unforgettable soliloquy. ldquoWersquore here tonight not to decideUFOs are real ndash unidentied flying objects clearly are real, he announced, steely-jawed, unblinking. ldquoSomething is in our skies. Wersquore here to discuss what they could be and from where they might originate.It didnrsquot matter that Trevor was likely reading some faceless producerrsquos hyperbolic spiel from an autocue. The signicance lay in the fact someone who didnrsquot cut his own hair or eat roadkill just told the nation UFOs were real.Even unbound by its ubiquitous acronym, unidentied flying objects being legitimised on ITV should have been a cultural watershed ndash a moment where even the most earthbound of cynics recalibrated their stance.Yet, nearly a quarter of a century later, the credibility of UFOs has lost much of its worth in terms of cultural currency. Even reputable sightings like the odd darting lights witnessed by several commercial airline pilots over Ireland recentlybarely registered a raised eyebrow.Perhaps, then, UFOs really are just a fading hangover from less informed times, when our species was far more susceptible to vague notions of the supernatural ndash before smartphone addiction stopped our minds from wandering, killing imagination, wonder and creativity stone dead.Perhaps Sir Trevorrsquos new gig chatting to folk with morals lower than snake testicles ndash not celebs, the monsters he salaciously affords the oxygen of publicity on his abhorrent Inside Death Row show ndash is also indicative of todayrsquos anaesthetised indference to anything thatrsquos not taking place within our own culture silos.Perhaps thedying scream of a world quickly spiralling into an uninhabitabledystopia is being deafened by the static of digital isolation. In such a dystopian, self-obsessed reality, it might actually take something as seismic as the sight of a UFO hovering over a major city to dig us out our deep burrows and unite us again as a species.Escape the netTHE smoking gun often held up by cynics dismissing the UFO phenomenon is the distinct lack of any clear photos in this smartphone-dominated era.Certainly, two major online sites for reporting sightings ndash the National UFO Reporting Center and the Mutual UFO Network ndash have both experienced numerical declines parallel to Gary Glitterrsquos royalty cheques.The internet itself can certainly shoulder some of the blame for UFOs fading fame too. Despite the initial promise that free access to information and instant communication could birth a more enlightened, empowered and equal world, a grotesque funfair mirror reflection of reality has instead haemorrhaged.Without gatekeepers, lies are now afforded an equal  to truth, and the ensuing static serves only to discombobulate focus and perception. In the era of spin, reality distortion, Photoshop and Deepfakes, good luck finding credible evidence of your own existence never mind UFOs. The internet is rather like communism ndash wonderful in theory, but the cradle of horror when human nature is added to the formulae.At times, however, some notable events do cut through the noise. Commercial pilots are certainly credible witnesses and that recentincident over the Irish sea proved that very strange things continue to happen in our skies ndash even odder than folk willingly paying pound for a coffee and biscuit.Some of the iniduals now coming forward to tell their stories are actually more plausible witnesses than those we trust to steer us through the clouds in a sky-dart ndash high ranking government employees and military personnel with nothing to gain and everything to lose. Yet, despite waving all manner of prestigious credentials, itrsquos likely they will be taken as seriously as folk who claim to have skinny-dipped with Nessie.Full DisclosureOVER the past few decades, there have been several ldquoofficial movements attempting to find some sort of objective truth on UFOs.The most high profile is lsquoDisclosurersquo, where ufologist Steven Greer herded  whistle-blowers ndash including astronaut Gordon Cooper and a brigadier general ndash for a fascinating press conference held in Washington DC in . The aim  To ldquoestablish the reality of extraterrestrial vehicles, le forms and exotic technologies".Yet, groups like Disclosure are finding it tough to gain publicity in the mainstream media, where editors have licked a finger and held it to the wind, deeming the public has lost its appetite for such frivolity in an age filled with real clear and present otherworldly dangers.But who needs the media as a conduit when the lying, conspiring governments themselves are now releasing the most intriguing and credible UFO evidence for public consumption Perhaps most jaw-dropping of all the recently declassied military footage released by the US Defence Department is an encounter between Navy F- fighters and several unidentied aircraft. The recording captures several pilots discussing a hovering egg-shaped craft, apparently one of a ldquofleet. Another film trumps that however ndash showing an F-rsquos close encounter with what is clearly, well, an unidentied flying object.More sober mindsets will speculatethis was simply space junk catching the sunrsquos light or even an advanced craft piloted by tiny Russians. Yet, such speculation itself suggests something even more terrying than the existence of UFOs ndash that we might actually be completely alone in the universe.The Pentagon comes cleanIF itrsquos a credible UFO whistleblower yoursquore after, perhaps someone with a lot to lose from being subject to ridicule from his peers, then Christopher Mellon is your man ndash a former deputy assistant Secretary of Defence for Intelligence for the Clinton and George W Bush administrations.Bemoaning the lack of transparent government investigations into valid sightings, Mellon recently told the Washington Post: ldquoI know from numerous discussions with Pentagon officials over the past two years that military departments and agencies treat such incidents as isolated events rather than as part of a pattern requiring serious attention and investigation.He also makes reference to his colleague Luis Elizondo - who used to run a Pentagon intelligence program examining evidence of ldquoanomalous aircraft - resigning in protest at the US governmentrsquos seeming indference to a ldquogrowing body of empirical data.ldquoNobody wants to be lsquothe alien guyrsquo in the national security bureaucracy, Mellon soberly concluded. ldquoNobody wants to be ridiculed or sidelined for drawing attention to the issue. Yet, the current attitude is a serious and recurring impediment to progress.Other declassied documents reveal that the US Air Force recently launched several F- fighters in a failed attempt to intercept an unidentied high-speed aircraft darting over the Pacic. Defence Department officials also confirmed more than a dozen similar incidents taking place off the US East Coast since .Itrsquos perhaps no coincidence that these stories emerged not long after the Pentagon itself publicly acknowledged the existence of a program dedicated to studying unidentied flying objects. The soberly-monikered Advanced Aviation Threat Identication Program ran from  to , but many officials claim its efforts have simply resumed under another name. Either way, admission of its existence has marked one of the most signicant disclosures about UFO government research since the infamous Project Blue Book, a y US Air Force study into thousands of sightings that was shut down in .Officially, Project Blue Book failed to find ldquoany technological developments or principles beyond the range of present-day scientic knowledge, yet a small number of its investigations remain unexplained. And thatrsquos the thing ndasheven one of the millions of UFO sightings is true, then the phenomenon is conclusively proven. Just one.Wharsquos like US FAR from being a spectacle confined to the toothless whispers of banjo prodigies, Scotland is no stranger to wee visits from aliens, interdimentional structures, highly evolved sky dragons and time travellers from the future. Perhaps all fouryoure in Port Glasgow.Just last year, an Airbus A with  people on board which was making its final approach into Glasgow airport, came within  feet of colliding with a ldquoblue, yellow and silver object, which pilots witnessed flying underneath it. The disturbed crew immediately contacted air traffic control, stating: ldquoNot quite sure what it was but itrsquos definitely quite large and itrsquos blue and yellow. Prestwick airport backed up the sighting, with radar detecting an ldquounidentied track history . miles east of the planes position  seconds earlier.However Scotlandrsquos most infamous UFO tale, unique in British history as the only example of a close encounter becoming the subject of a criminal investigation, is known as The Livingston Incident. Forestry worker Robert Taylor claims he saw "a huge flying dome" in woodland near Dechmont Law on November , , describing it as seven metres in diameter, and made of a dark metallic material with a rough texture like sandpaper.Taylor claimed to have experienced an acrid smell "like burning brakes" and the sensation of being dragged. When police visited the site, they found marks in the soil where the craft was said to have hovered, and further tracks following the path of two ldquomine-like objects. Taylor, who died in , never sought publicity or financial gain ndash and always stood by his account.Perhaps he would have found a more sympathetic audience in Bonnybridge, home of the infamous Falkirk Trianglersquo. This well-kent ndash and henceforth thoroughly monetised ndash phenomenon was first reported in  and the area still continues to register around  sightings a year, more than any other place on Earth ndash even more than the notorious Area  in Nevada. The fact it attracts a lot of UFO tourists who are perhaps inclined to believe in the phenomenon ndash and also want their moneys worth ndash is neither here nor there, of course.Scots UFO expert Ron Halliday says: "One theory is that there could be a window into another dimension, other worlds, the past or the future. Even Nessie probably thinks thats a bit outlandish. Although where  would you visit but Scotlandthis planet is simply some sort of space zoo for holidaying Zeta Reticulians And finally hellipTemporal lobe epilepsy is an unenviable yet fascinating condition that many doctors deem entirely responsible for all occurances of inexplicable supernatural phenomena, from UFOs to religious communion to the indeterminate forces holding Donald Trumprsquos barnet together.Those afflicted may not be aware of their condition, unwittingly suffering brief seizures, paralysis, vivid hallucinations and ndash notably ndash an overwhelming feeling of something other in their vicinity.If UFOs are indeed a purely internally projected phenomenon, we can then safely assume such stories would likely reflect current sociological, technological and cultural fears and aspirations.Certainly during the Cold War, the beings described in these close encounters were often characterised as benign saviours who wanted to help humans overcome the prospect of nuclear annihilation.And after events such as Watergate and the Vietnam war fuelled mass distrust in government, witnesses came to describe UFOs as a threat to humanity ndash their sinister and all-powerful occupants often rendering abductees powerless and repeatedly probing themagainst their will. Ananalogymost conspiracy theorists who believe theactionsof the mainstream media areorchestrated by a puppet master elite willbe familiar.A version of thisarticle was published previously in The Herald

title: Marianne Taylor  The lockdown exit plan is ageist  Over-70s can decide what   s best for their health
story: They are a mixture of the married, orced and widowed. Some are lonely, others not. They live in dferent parts of the country, come from dferent socio-economic backgrounds, have dferent desires and goals.So why are they being treated as one homogenous, vulnerable group, and condemned to an indefinite lockdown While it looks like those of us aged  and under may soon be allowed to restart our lives as part of the lockdown exit plan ndash albeit cautiously and while following social distancing measures ndash it seems the over-s may be told by the Scottish and UK governments to keep self-isolating for up to  months. Maybe longer.Such a blanket policy surely has ageism at its core, regardless of how well-intentioned. How  do you explain the assumption that everyone over the age of  is weak and incapable of making decisions about their own health and wellbeing The evidence from UK Covid- wards suggests the average age of a critically ill patient is . Nine out of  have underlying conditions such as high blood pressure, obesity or type  diabetes. We also know, of course, this cruel illness can afflict, sometimes kill, young and fit people.Until a vaccine is widely available ndash an endeavour scientists believe may take  months or more ndash many people with underlying health conditions of every age group will obviously want to take maximum care and precautions to prevent exposing themselves to danger. They accept, hard as it may be, that they wonrsquot be able to leave home. Others wonrsquot have the mental capacity to make these decisions for themselves.But what about over-s that are fitter, healthier and more active than their younger relatives and friends  And what about older people who do suffer from underlying health problems but would rather take a dferent approach once restrictions start to be lted They may decide it is worth leaving home, spending time with grandchildren and friends, going shopping, evenit means an increased chance of catching the virus. They may be willing to accept the associated risks and consequences.Whatrsquos so galling is the idea that no-one over  can or should decide for themselves what risks they are willing to take with their own health and wellbeing.One of most interesting aspects of this crisis has been the way it has forced all of us to examine and question what makes le worth living. Many of us, myself included, will have come to the conclusion that social contact, time spent with other human beings, is the most precious thing in our lives.This is certainly the case for most of the older folk I speak tonow, especially those who have lost their partner and or live alone. Spending time with children, grandchildren, siblings and pals is what keeps them going. It doesnrsquot take a PhD in psychology to work out that Skype and Zoom will only suffice for so long.I was walking in an empty Glasgow city centre recently and the saddest thing of all was the absence of the cheery bands of elderly ladies and gents that usually frequent Sauchiehall Street on week days, comparing prices and purchases, enjoying a cuppa and a scone, or a pint. The thought of them home alone indefinitely, stoic as they may be, is heartbreaking. For some in care homes, extended isolation will be torturous.Itrsquos one thing ordering people to live without friends and family for a few weeks. Itrsquos something  entirely telling them to do so for months, maybe years. Even for their own good. Some, especially those in the autumn of their lives, may understandably decide it is a sacrice they are not willing to make.There has been much talk recently about treating people like adults. This must include the over-s, who, letrsquos face it, have been grown up for longer than anybody .To be clear, I am not advocating reckless breaking of current lockdown rules. Irsquom saying we need a sensible approach to what comes next, one that doesnrsquot discriminate against the elderly. One that ensures le is still worth living.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: history-3d-new-images-bring-museum-exhibits-life-home
story: With a flick of the hand, the historic vessel ndash built in  on the north banks of the Clyde ndash spins  degrees, revealing a stern that juts above the propellerrsquos curved blades and a large, semi-circular rudder.Zoom in and itrsquos possible to examine her decaying deckhouse. There, a fragile-looking banister guides the viewerrsquos eye along the upper edge of a staircase leading down into the boatrsquos bowels.Such detail would not normally be available to those visiting the Carolarsquos final resting place at the Scottish Maritime Museum.But now, thanks to technology, every last stain, bolt and rust patch on what is believed to be worldrsquos oldest seagoing steam yacht can be scrutinised at any time and from the comfort of home.She is one of several vessels captured as part of a landmark D scanning project that was spearheaded by some of the worldrsquos leading cultural organisations, including the revered Smithsonian Institution in the US and the National Gallery of Denmark. Experts at Dundee University Museum Collections were also involved.The result of their work is a huge online store offering the public free, unrestricted access to hundreds of models through the Sketchfab content-sharing .As well as the Carola, there are images of MV Spartan, the only surviving Scottish-built ldquopuffer, and RNLB Jane Anne, a rare surviving example of a double-ended, self-righting leboat which is hugely important to the Maritime Museumrsquos local community of Irvine.Staff at Dundee University, meanwhile, scanned specimens preserved in its globally famous zoological collection.Among the overseas items featured are the Smithsonianrsquos Apollo  Columbia command module, a Tyrannosaurus Rex skull from the Digital Atlas of Ancient Le and a fourth century BC sculpture held by the Minneapolis Institute of Art.Marta Pilarska, D Digitisation Project Manager at the Maritime Museum, said the models would create an entirely new relationship with members of the public.ldquoAll of a sudden ... we have this digital output that can serve not only as a condition-monitoring tool but is also visually appealing, she explained.ldquoWe can use it to engage with the public and allow online visitors to explore our collection in a new way. One of the benefits of this ndash particularlyyoursquore talking about vessels such as MV Spartan and SY Carola ndash is that while visiting the Museum in Irvine one can view the vessels from the outside, but access to interiors is restricted.ldquoImmersive virtual tours, based on -degree imaging, enabled us to make those areas accessible.However, the technical challenges were signicant.ldquoWersquove had to move quickly through a big but rewarding learning curve, said Ms Pilarska.ldquoD laser scanning and photogrammetry are the two main techniques used in digital recording of heritage sites and objects."Photogrammetry is the one used more often in the museum sector, as it is regarded as being easier and more budget-friendly. In short, it comes down to taking hundreds of images from all around the object and processing them in a software capable of recognising distinctive features of these objects and hellip digitally reconstructing the objectrsquos geometry. Based on that, the D model is built."Laser scanning, on the other hand, guarantees high accuracy and is considered a standard D surveying method.ldquoWhenever a laser beam sent from the scanner hits the surface of the object and s to the sensor, it is recorded as a precise measurement. Scanners send and record millions of such beams during data capture and all of them are stored as points in D space, or point clouds. Those point clouds are then what underpins the accurate D model."Ms Pilarska hopes the scans will become a huge online draw while the Maritime Museum itself is closed under coronavirus lockdown measures.But the project, she stressed, was not solely about boosting interaction with the public. Building up detailed information about the vessels themselves was another key aim.ldquoHaving an accurate record of the museum collection was one of two reasons to have this project happen, she said. ldquoPublic access is the second.ldquoCreating detailed documentation of museum collections has always been one of the fundamentals of curatorsrsquo work, and D documentation feels like the next step that the sector will take with advancements in technology.Over at Dundee University, Dr Caroline Erolin and her students scanned specimens from the world-famous DrsquoArcy Thompson Zoology Museum. Among the more unusual and exotic contributions are a sea turtle carapace, a pencil urchin and a rhinoceros hindfoot.For Ms Erolin, a senior lecturer in medical art, questions over how much of the universityrsquos collection would be posted touched on a growing debate around ensuring that public access to artefacts does not come at the expense of a proper appreciation of their origin.ldquoTherersquos a movement to say that everything should be totally open access and rights-free for the public, she said.ldquoThe counter argument is that objects can then be viewed and shared without anything about their cultural context, where they have come from.ldquoWe wanted to take part but not put the whole collection up online and make the entire thing open access.ldquoSo we put  objects online, totally open access, and around another  more under a lsquonon-commercial, attribution, share-alikersquo licence, although people like members of the general public can still download thosethey want to.ldquoWe will see how that goes and may make more open access in the future.Ms Erolin said the availability of the Sketchfab store felt particularly important as the coronavirus lockdown continues and Scots look for sources of mental stimulation at home.ldquoIt definitely has value terms of public outreach, she added.ldquoMatthew Jarron, the museum curator, was quite keen because [the museum] is campus-based and itrsquos not open to the public that often.ldquoWe thought it would be nice to have certain specimens more accessible on a permanent basis.ldquoMembers of the public can download the scanned images free, then D print them. So there are multiple aspects of it from a public engagement point of view.ldquoOf course, this was before coronavirus and so itrsquos timely to have that dferent means of access.ldquoEven when the museum is open, itrsquos maybe a bit harder for some people ndash the disabled, for example - to access it, so it just widens access in the general sense.It is also possible the store will continue growing.ldquoI donrsquot knowwe will realistically scan everything," she said. "But perhaps, with an internship, we will have someone coming in and doing a few more scans and plan to keep building it up.

title: scientists-discover-scots-witnessed-end-world-werent-fish-time
story: IN the somewhat fancul plotof Hollywood blockbusterArmageddon, the lsquoworldrsquos greatest deep sea drillerrsquo Harry Stiller ndash played by a stoic, steely-jawed Bruce Willis ndash has his unique skillset procured by NASA and findshimself blasted off to the surface of an incoming asteroid ... to blow it out of the sky with anuclear bomb.Highly dubious science aside, the Box Office success of Armageddon did serve to highlight a very real threat to the human racersquos survival that is perhaps even more sobering than pandemics such as coronavirus ndash huge asteroids on a trajectory to Earth with the potential to wipe out much of the planetrsquos biological le.Certainly, the astral body that flew past this Wednesday ndash Asteroid OR, to give the two mile-long rock its Sunday name - would have wiped out much of the planetrsquos organic matter,it hadnrsquot soared past at a relatively near-miss of  times the Earth-Moon distance.Asteroidwas the biggest fly-by expected this year, with professional and amateur observers watching it pass as a slow-moving lsquostarrsquo. More visible to the naked eye, however -le hadnrsquot been confined to the oceans at the time ndash would have been the huge object that smashed off the north west coast of Scotland . billion years ago, an event recently discoveredby geologists.A team of UK researchers have uncovered signs of a huge asteroid collision in the Stac Fada deposit in the Northwest Highlands, with rocks there containing high levels of chemicals found in asteroids.They also detected quartz crystals which have been subjected to intense pressures and heat - leading researchers to believe they have pinpointed the exact spot where the asteroid hit.Academics from the University of Oxford and the University of Exeter claim the impact crater lies between nine and  miles off the coast in the Minch, which separates the mainland from the Outer Hebrides.Today, the spot is buried beneath water and rocks, rendering it inaccessible - so they pinpointed the possible site bystudying the alignment of magnetic particles and distribution of debris thrown outwards at the time of the collision.ldquoIf you imagine debris flowing out in a big cloud across the landscape, hugging the ground, eventually that material slows down and comes to rest, said study author Kenneth Amor. ldquoBut itrsquos the stuff out in front that stops first while the stuff behind is still pushing forward and it overlaps whatrsquos in front.ldquoThatrsquos what we see and it gives us a strong directional indicator that we can trace backwards.The huge asteroid, estimated to have been between . and . miles wide, is believed to have struck when Scotland was a still a semi-arid environment located near the equator. Amor estimates the crater resulting from the impact spans almost nine miles in , with a depth of around . miles ndash making it the biggest ever astral collision ever discovered in the UK.Experts believe meteorite strikes were relatively common billions of years ago, as Earth and other planets were pelted with debris left over from the formation of the solar system.Amor says the new research marks such an exciting discovery because impact craters typically erode over time.ldquoIt was purely by chance that this one landed in an ancient rt valley where fresh sediment quickly covered the debris to preserve it, he states.Now that the craterrsquos possible location has been discovered, scientists aim to conduct targeted, D geophysical surveys of the Minch Basin.High-resolution surveys could help the research team get a better sense of the dimensions of the crater - and might even have important implications for other celestial bodieswe learn more about their composition and trajectory.ldquoImpact craters on Earth are exceedingly rare, Amor said. ldquoThe better we can understand how they formed the better we can understand observations on the rocky planets and moons of the solar system.--------------------------------------------------Space enthusiasts get ready to rockGlasgow academics call for volunteers to help collect meteorites as part of UK Fireball NetworkSCOTTISH scientists are turning their eyes to the skies to track meteorites ndash smaller, less threatening iations of their asteroid cousins - before they land on UK soil and want volunteers to help recover the space rocks wherever they fall.The UK Fireball Network, led by researchers from the University of Glasgow and Imperial College London is setting out to place  cameras across the country to catch glimpses of the spectacular natural firework displays caused when meteoroids enter the Earthrsquos atmosphere.It is part of a wider network called the Global Fireball Observatory operated by researchers in Australia at Curtin University.Earlier this year in February, the networkrsquos cameras filmed their first fireball, which dropped meteorites into the North Sea.SKYFALL:Volunteers will help scientists search for traces of meteorites which have been tracked on camera.While those are impossible to recover, the network team expect that future sightings that fall on the UK landmass can be properly triangulated to determine a landing area and send out a search party to find future meteorites.Dr Luke Daly, of the University of Glasgowrsquos School of Geographical and Earth Sciences, is one of the leaders of the UK Fireball Network. He said: ldquoMeteorites provide scientists with invaluable insights into other planets and our solar system. A good deal of what we know about the surface of Mars, for example, comes from analysis of chunks of the planet which were blasted off its surface by asteroid impacts millions of years ago and drted in space before falling to Earth.ldquoMeteorites enter our atmosphere all the time, but the UK hasnrsquot had a great track record of finding them ndash in fact, itrsquos been nearly  years since one was last seen dropping into a back garden in Glatton in Cambridgeshire, and more than  since one was observed in Scotland.ldquoCamera networks like ours, and those of partner organisations like UKMON and SCAMP, give us a great chance to capture fireballs on multiple cameras.ldquoTogether we are building an integrated pipeline to use all the data from all the networks to track fireballs called the UK Fireball Alliance.ldquoIt was very exciting to capture our first images of a fireball caught by two of our observatories, although it was obviously disappointing that the material it dropped fell into the sea.ldquoWhen we do catch sight of a fireball dropping meteorites on land, wersquoll need the help of volunteers to help comb the countryside to find them, so anyone interested in making a little bit of history by getting involved can follow us on Twitter at @FireballsUK.

title: coronavirus-scotland-councils-told-use-reserves-155m-support-withheld
story: Last month, the UK Government announced an additional pound. billion was being handed over to local authorities - with pound million given to the Scottish Government as part of funding conesquentials.But Finance Secretary Kate Forbes is refusing to hand over the money to Scottish councils until she is satisfied with how much they need.Ms Forbes has written to COSLA, the umbrella organisation representing Scottish councils, suggesting that authorities dip into their reserves instead.Edinburgh City Council has warned it faces increased costs and loss of cash of more than pound millionthe shutdown last for six months, while Highlands Council has also stressed it could see an extra pound million added to its financial pressures.The issue was raised by Conservative MSP, Graham Simpson, who told Ms Forbes that local councils were "hopping mad" about the situation.:Coronavirus: Edinburgh Council needs radical action to plug poundm pandemic gapMr Simpson said: "On April , Robert Jenrick announced that councils in England were to get an extra pound. billion to help in the effort against Covid-."Scotland would get pound million in consequentials from that - but councils here havenrsquot yet heardthey are going to receive a penny of that money and to put it mildly, they are hopping mad about that."Labour local government spokesperson, Sarah Boyack, said it was "critical" that councils are given certainty from the Scottish Government.She added: "They have already transformed their services for our communities and staff through the pandemic, their incomes have already been reduced and they already had existing budget pressures. Canrsquot we just get that trust from the Scottish Government ""They are working together and we need to make sure that our local authorities have that certainty going forward so they can plan now for the future we are all needing them to deliver for us.":Council leaders call for new funding model to give local authorities more powerMs Forbes said the Scottish Government is "committed to deploying any consequentials we receive in a way that is helpful to local government and to the wider Covid response".But she has not guaranteedor when the poundm will be handed over to Scottish councils.She said: "I donrsquot dispute the financial challenges facing our public services just now and working closely with COSLA. I do think itrsquos only right that we understand what the costs are before we come to conclusions on how we use those consequentials to support local authorities."I do think itrsquos remarkable that we are being pressed just now to provide funding in advance of COSLA confirming what their cost pressures are."It seems to me perfectly reasonable thatCOSLA has committed to a cost-gathering exercise, and clearly there are cost implications, that we understand what that funding need is before we come to a settled conclusion on the funding available."But in a letter sent to Gail Macgregor, COSLAs resources spokesperson, Ms Forbes stressed that she wants to "understand how those costs are being mitigated by the funding measures we have already committed" before the cash is handed over.She added: "I also want to consider what further reprioritisation we could undertake jointly to free up resources to meet the cost challenges now and in the future, along with the use of local government reserves and applications to the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme to help contain the costs.":Communities lsquoat riskrsquo by proposed cuts to local authoritiesConservatives have criticised the pressure put on councils to dip into their reserves, which are already under pressure and dwindling in a bid to meet day-to-day costs, by the Scottish Government.Scottish Conservative leader Jackson Carlaw said: ldquoCouncils came into this crisis ill-equipped to cope after years of the SNP slashing their budgets to the bone. ldquoNow, instead of passing on the money they need, the Finance Secretary is telling them to raid their reserves even further. ldquoSome local authorities barely have any reserves left thanks to the SNPrsquos botched approach to funding. ldquoAnd rather than hand over all the Barnett consequentials in full ndash money that was specically targeted for local authorities ndash the SNP wants to short-change councils even more severely." Labour finance spokesperson, Jackie Baillie, has accused SNP ministers of a "cash grab" on local councils.She added: "Even the SNPs own councillors say that this money, which is supposed to fund highly pressured council services to weather this national emergency, should go to councils. But ministers seem determined to centralise control of these funds."This is emergency funding which should go directly to councils to help fund social care without any further delay. It is outrageous that the Scottish Government is sitting on its hands."COSLA is calling for the money earmarked for local council to be handed over immediately.Ms Macgregor said: "Council leaders were clear yesterday that the reaction of councils to the Covid- epidemic, ensuring essential services are secured, and that our most vulnerable people are protected has been a remarkable effort and as such the pound million of consequentials should be passed to local government immediately. ldquoCouncils are working hard to keep a huge range of essential services running to meet the needs of communities and to be responsive locally. But the bottom line is that protecting people and providing services costs money.":Coronavirus: Scottish Governments partial business support u-turn still falls shortShe added:ldquoThat is why, when the pound.billion of funding was announced by the UK Government for councils in England over two weeks ago, we immediately wrote to the Scottish Government in relation to the poundmillion of consequentials for Scottish councils. I will continue to keep discussions going with Kate Forbes on this issue. Council Leaders emphatic that the poundmillion of Consequentials come to Local Government immediately. Quote from @COSLA Resources Spokesperson @CllrGMacgregor pic yBwyAPIUfldquoWhilst we fully appreciate the pressure facing the Cabinet at this time, councils are facing an extremely challenging situation on the ground, with signicant additional costs being incurred on a daily basis, as well as massive losses of income as a result of the lock down. The response from Scottish Government so far does nothing to alleviate the collective concerns of Scottish Local Government and we call on the consequentials to be passed to Local Government immediately.

title: coronavirus-scotland-catholic-church-draws-plans-phased-reopening-parishes
story: It will establish a working group of outside advisers to draw up a strategy that would allow buildings to open again and Masses to .Some of these measures were already in place ahead of lockdown as the Covid- pandemic grew in Scotland.:Amazon Prime launch for documentary into Scots surgeons miracle cure for drug addictionBishop John Keenan, of Paisley Diocese, said the Church has been in discussions with the Scottish Government over issues such as funerals, which have been restricted to immediate family of the deceased.An independent group will now be formed to draw up a strategy but Bishop Keenan said some changes to normal practice will be needed."We are not going to ask for our churches to be open when we dont think it is safe," he told the PA news agency."One priest in a big church looked at social distancing - he had a church of  and he said that the maximum you could get in was , maybe two to a bench for instance."He said parishes have been hit financially by the closures."Our diocese, we are OK for the first part of the year but the longer it goes on the tougher it will get," he said."Most Catholics still want to give money to the Church on a weekly basiswe would give them means to do so."Some have been furloughed or lost jobs so they might not be able to but a lot have been contacting their parish priest to ask how to donate."I think ultimately we will be fine becausewe put in place natural and easy means where people can donate they will do so."Other plans include giving those who have lost loved ones during the pandemic an opportunity to say goodbye, as they may have been restricted from being present in the hospital or at the funeral.Bishop Keenan said: "Every priest I would say has buried someone with Covid.:Half of Scotlands care workers paid less than Real Living Wage"We are conscious that once the lockdown is over well need to provide means for the family to grieve."In a message to parishioners, Archbishop Leo Cushley, of St Andrews and Edinburgh Archdiocese, said: "Were doing what we can as bishops to speak to the Government and the authorities so that we are exploring how to move forward, what the next steps will be and how to open our churches as soon as we possibly can do so, doing it safely and doing it well."A Scottish Government spokesman said: "We are in regular contact with all of Scotlands faith leaders and communities in order to understand their concerns and needs during this time, however, current guidance remains to stay at home and only travel where it is essential so there are currently no plans to reopen places of worship."We will engage in further discussion before communities might safely begin to consider reopening places of worship for services at the time it is safe to do so."

title: tributes-paid-late-qc-activist-derek-ogg-65
story: Mr Ogg, who worked as a Crown prosecutor and as a defence advocate, campaigned for the  law which automatically pardoned gay and bisexual men convicted of sexual offences that are no longer illegal.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon led the tributes, saying, Mr Ogg was a "brilliant advocate and a truly lovely man".She added: "It was always a pleasure for me to hear from him on issues he felt strongly about, and I will miss his wisdom and good sense."Gordon Jackson QC, dean of Faculty of Advocates, said: "All of us who knew Derek Ogg are deeply saddened by his passing."He was a marvellous advocate but more than that he was a fierce campaigner for his beliefs both on a personal and professional level. title: vicky-allan-feeling-burnt-home-school-home-work
story: def. exhausted or in poor health due to overworkThere have been many times over the past few weeks when itrsquos seemed to me that the much-talked of coronavirus slowness was a myth, or something Irsquod failed, personally, to grasp. At first I thought I was the only person feeling this, but then I started to realise many others were too. People I come in contact with kept telling me they felt more busy, not less ndash and Irsquom not just talking about key workers, but a wide demographic in terms of income and occupation. These people, of course, were mostly not those who had been furloughed or lost work. They were also, mostly, people who had kids.Last week, this paper reported that millions of people forced to work from home ldquomay be at risk of burnout as their work-le balance is turned upside down. It may seem hyperbolic for us to talk about feeling burnt out by just the mere challenge of trying to work and home-school our children, but therersquos a pace of le for many of us here thatrsquos undoubtedly unsustainable. Irsquom waking at am to get time to work before home school starts, and Irsquove talked to many others stretching out their days, doing their double shts.We may be moving around less, but many of us are as busy. When our cars, trains, planes and workplaces stopped, tech rushed in ndash Zoom, Microsoft Teams, streamed talks and events ndash and not just for us, but also for our children. On Facebook this week I found myself joining in on a thread, started by a parent with a small business, who complained that she was struggling to get to grips with the confusing system of online school assignments being sent out to her kids.It echoed my own feelings that one of the biggest challenges of the recent weeks had been to try to work out what my eldest son, at secondary school, is expected to do. He wants to manage it himself, but it seems unmanageable. Work arrives on dferent s ndash via email, Teams, website downloads ndash with assignments often not where you expect them to be.Reports into lockdown delivery of online education are revealing a staggering dference between inidual schools, and crucially between the state and private sector. Neil Mackay, writing in this paper last week, reported that a survey by the Scottish Secondary Teachersrsquo Association before Easter found that less than half of children were engaging with teachers. He described how one teacher had told him she only had four children out of  join an online lesson. I recognise that. My son was one of three in such a low turn-out class and only because we happened to spot the message when it came in.And I understand why kids arenrsquot engaging. It feels to me asour childrenare being thrown in at the deep end and the swimming skills they have to learn are a form of digital self-management. Some may emerge at the end having learned practices of self-organisation, but many will not. Some, in some houses, have no access to digital learning at all. Irsquom not blaming the inidual teachers, many of whom are locked in a struggle of trying to deliver learning through new technology s, while also possibly juggling their own kids. I also think itrsquos wrong to blame parents. The wider system itself should deliver a lot better for all kids.Gratefuldef. feeling or showing an appreciation for something done or receivedI ALSO, however, think that children are part of a wider world, and above all we need to be working out right now how to make this better for all of us in the new normal.The truth is Irsquom someone who believes in slowness. I take on board Danny Dorlingrsquos argument that evidence shows we are already going through a period of technological slowdown, economic deceleration and declining growth.But it feels aseven in this pause, le for many of us is only getting more digitally hectic. We could resist that ndash let our kids get bored and drop out at work ndash but most of us are still struggling to earn and the answers to many of our current problems demand work. They also require rethinking whatrsquos important ndash and, what with home school and homework, many of us are too busy for that.Feeling wakeful  The Covid pandemic, a recipe for insomniaVicky Allan is feeling grateful. How coronavirus is showing us a new gratitude

title: celebrating-500-miles-road-brought-prosperity-plaudits
story: The majestic scenery should easily sell itself ndash rolling mountains, sandy beaches fringed by rocky clfs, historic castles, eerie plains and isolated villages.Yet for years, Scotlandrsquos northern coastline was either simply too far away, too much trouble to reach, with apparently nothing to do and just not well enough known about for many tourists to bother with.That, of course, was before the arrival of Scotlandrsquos biggest tourism phenomenon, a simple but devastatingly effective marketing masterstroke which has brought an unprecedented visitor boom to some of the nationrsquos most remote nooks and crannies.Launched in  in the hope it might boost Scotlandrsquos struggling northerly communities, the North Coast  has raced past the likes of Americarsquos Route  to be regularly named among the worldrsquos greatest road trips and a bucket list ldquomust do for people around the world.Five years on, what began as a hopeful plan to throw a spotlight on Scotlandrsquos lesser visited northern coast has put small communities, rollercoaster single-track roads, once almost deserted campsites, restaurants and hotels on the tourist map almost all year round.Now, with international tourism in tatters and the thoughts of many turning to when lockdown might be eased, there is every likelihood more Scots than ever before may well follow the lead of tens of thousands of visitors who have already explored the -mile route.Tom Campbell, chief executive of the North Highland Initiativeand who came up with the idea of a north coast touring route, says the ldquoseismic change in how Scots and other UK nations holiday as a result of Covid- could result in a staycation boom, helping to ensure the success of the NC and businesses along the route continues through dficult times.ldquoAirline holidays are going to be more expensivethey are even possible, he says. ldquoI think wersquoll see more UK visitors heading to Scotland and driving will be the way people will want to take their holidays.ldquoThe NC is ideally suited to that. The open spaces, the fresh air and all the things that make the route special havenrsquot changed ndash the seascapes are still there, the landscape is still amazing, the food from sea and land, and the infrastructure is still there.ldquoCovid- has meant we have had to hit the pause button, but all the reasons that made NC the number one route in the world have not changed.The NC winds its way north from Inverness to Dornoch, Wick and Dunnet Head, traversing the roof of Scotland before twisting and turning its way along the west coast and crossing back to its starting point.Travellers could simply plot their own course around the routersquos scenic attractions, but many opt to become paid-up members of the NC travel ldquoclub, giving them precious access to inside information and advice to make their experience more enjoyable.An overwhelming number of tourists who complete the route give it a giant ldquothumbs up ndash % according to the routersquos  visitor survey. What began as an initiative to bring some fresh opportunities to the area was last year estimated to have boosted the economy by pound. million and created around  full-time jobs.For businesses, travellers in their cars, campervans, motorbikes and even cycles have brought unexpected prosperity. Room occupancy for hotels and bed and breakfasts has soared from around % to around % ndash in some places even higher ndash with room rates almost doubling in price. Attractions from distilleries to museums, restaurants, shops, campsites and castles have all reported giant leaps in visitor numbers.Yet, as Campbell points out, the routersquos incredible success wasnrsquot entirely expected. ldquoWe launched in May  with a spring in our step ndash we had an audience reach of , at that point. By , that audience had grown to . billion, he adds.Along the way have been key moments that have embedded the route into the minds of prospective tourists around the world. ldquoNot for a minute did I imagine that Aston Martin would one day approach us and askthey could create a new DB limited edition around the NC, adds Campbell.ldquoOr that Jeremy Clarkson would describe it as lsquothe best route in the worldrsquo and that the journey from Ullapool to Gairlochrsquos scenery was so spectacular thatThe Melvich Hotel by Thurso has been a spot for travellers to rest since the s.But, like many businesses along its -mile route, the launch of the NC five years ago has transformed it from what had been a far-flung destination for a few hardy travellers.ldquoIt used to be we got older couples with time and money to spend on travelling, says Jo Wyke, who runs the hotel with husband, Robert.ldquoThe NC has breathed new le into the area, people are realising there is a lot to do and wersquore seeing dferent kinds of visitors, people looking for adventure, surfers, people who want outdoor sports.ldquoWe were getting people from all the world, and starting to see visitors from India, the Far East, China, Russia and Latin American countries.ldquoThe last couple of years have been record-breakers for us which is down to the NC.

title: surrogate-mums-left-holding-baby-covid-19-rules
story: The first cuddle and the journey home for a new le together are among the most precious first moments of parenthood.However, couples who have spent years planning to become parents via a surrogate pregnancy are now facing the heart-breaking reality of missing priceless early moments of their babyrsquos le.Social distancing rules and Covid- lockdown have left parents-to-be facing a nightmare scenario of not being able to be close by for their babyrsquos birth, and even raised the complex issue of how they might meet their precious newborn and bring them home.Meanwhile, tight restrictions over hospital visits to maternity wards could also leave surrogate mothers facing the dilemma of having to care for the baby ndash with all the potential emotional conflict that might bring ndash or refusing to look after it at all.It could lead to babies being handed over in car parks and laybys or, worse, placed in the care of social services or foster parents while efforts are made to unite them with their intended parents.The situation has led to calls for social distancing rules to be relaxed so at least one intended parent can be allowed into maternity wards during the birth and throughout the babyrsquos hospital stay.One Edinburgh couple awaiting the birth in August of their first child via a Sunderland-based surrogate said their hopes of being able to savour precious moments of being with their baby straight after birth have been thrown into disarray by the pandemic.ldquoWe donrsquot know what will happen when baby is born, said Kevin Doebrich, who with husband Chris Kelly has been preparing for parenthood for three-and-a-half years.ldquoIf we are still under lockdown, we wonrsquot be allowed to go to hospital for the birth.ldquoWe are hearing from others who are having a baby now that what happens is very much on a case-by-case basis.ldquoSurrogacy is fairly rare and with everything going on in hospitals just now, itrsquos not a high priority.The couple have hired a private midwe amid hopes that their surrogate, Linder Wilkinson, , can have a home birth. However,strict lockdown rules are in place, there could be a question of whether even travelling from their Edinburgh home to Sunderland to collect their baby will be outlawed.ldquoEverything depends on what happens with the baby nearer the time, and whether it will have to be a hospital birth, added Chris. ldquoWe will deal with whatever the situation is. We are just looking forward to being parents.NHS trusts across the UK also have strict rules restricting scans, antenatal appointments and classes to just the pregnant woman, leading to concerns that intended parents are missing key moments and information related to their baby.Instead, Chris, , and Kevin, , are relying on videos filmed by their surrogate Linder which show their baby kicking and making recordings of themselves reading stories to be played to the growing baby so it becomes aware of their voices.ldquoThe key thing from day one has been that Linder is healthy and the baby is healthy, added Kevin. ldquoMissing the -week scan was disheartening and we were sad, but also ecstatic. We are just trying to crack on.Under normal circumstances, maternity wards allow intended parents to spend time in hospital after the birth enabling the surrogate ndash although legally the infantrsquos mother ndash to have no role in its care.However, there are fears surrogate mothers may now feel pressured to take over caring responsibilities such as feeding, bathing and nappy changes, and to make decisions over the babyrsquos care while waiting to be discharged.Linder, who has previously delivered surrogate babies to two other couples, said: ldquoI understand the reasons for restrictions, but there is a need to make an exception.ldquoThe baby will have two parents who are willing to look after it. I have no biological link with the baby and Irsquom not prepared to provide care for the baby ongoing, because itrsquos not right for me to do that.She added: ldquoIrsquove heard of surrogates having to look after the baby until they are discharged. Irsquove also heard of hospitals allowing the surrogate to be discharged while a parent goes in to look after the baby until it is ready to leave, which is much better. Itrsquos really important that Chris and Kevin can be there and have those first moments with their baby.There are also concerns that the legal processes which pass on full parental rights may be delayed due to Covid-, potentially leaving families in limbo for months.Olivia Rowlands, , whose womb was damaged by bowel cancer treatment which also sparked early menopause, and husband Sam, , from St Andrews, have also had their hopes of attending their babyrsquos birth thrown into confusion.Ellie Hutchinson, , from Stirling, Oliviarsquos cousin, is due to give birth to the couplersquos daughter by planned caesarean section in July.Olivia said: ldquoWe really donrsquot know what will happen during the birth.ldquoWe had hoped we could both be there ndash I canrsquot imagine not being able to see Samrsquos face when our baby is born. Wersquore not surethat will be possible.ldquoAfter the birth is a really tricky part. Ellie really wants Sam and I to be the ones who look after our daughter as soon as shersquos born and we want this to be as easy as possible for her.ldquoOn paper, Ellie is the legal mum. I canrsquot imagine the doctors saying I canrsquot be there and making Ellie look after the little one. Wersquore trying to be optimistic and positive.Meanwhile, couples at an earlier stage in their surrogacy journey who have invested years of planning and thousands of pounds on medical and legal procedures have also seen their dreams of parenthood stalled by a rules surrounding IVF and fertility treatment.Stuart Young, , and partner Gordon Anderson, , are currently waiting for an egg donor. Stuart said: ldquoWe donrsquot really know how long a delay this will cause, we are at the mercy of the rules stopping all fertility treatment.ldquoSurrogacy is incredibly complicated and complex with rules and regulations that we have had to learn about.ldquoWe had already resigned ourselves to the fact it would take a while. We just donrsquot want to be in our mid-to-late s and still be in this position.ldquoWe would love to be parents, itrsquos a dream we both have and we just have to focus on what we want.

title: rons-spotlight-however-view-creation-great-britain-no-doubt-violently-opposed-majority-scots
story: The days opened with the bells of St Giles Cathedral ringing out on May the First in , legally uniting Scotland and England as the Act of Union came into force. The tune the bells played was at the very least ambivalent about the newly-forged connection, Why Should I Be Sad On My Wedding Day.Well, maybe, although the hostility to the conjoining is underestimated. However you view the creation of what was to be Great Britain there is no doubt it was vigorously and violently opposed by the majority of Scots.Riots in Edinburgh and other Scottish towns in the months and years leading up to it had become a feature of everyday le. The Duke of Hamilton, who led the nationalist opposition , was cheered along the Royal Mile as he passed each day in his carriage, whereas the Duke of Queensberry, who supported the deal, required round-the-clock protection from hostile mobs chucking not just epithets but anything they could lay their hands on.When Daniel Defoe arrived in the city in  in his day job as an English secret agent, he described ldquoa Scots rabble is the worst of its kind, while conceding that ldquofor every Scot in favour of the union there were  opposed.Scotland had been all but bankrupted by the Darien scheme to build a colony on the plague-afflicted isthmus of Panama although as most of the population had nothing to lose, their level of poverty remained as crushing and deadly as it had before. It was the nobles and rich speculators, who had gambled and lost in the mad venture, who were hustling it through on the promise of a better time, mainly for themselves as they were to receive more than half of their losses ed.The Edinburgh parliament represented Scottish opinion only in a theoretical sense, made up as it was of self-perpetuating noblemen and landowners, but this was true of all parliaments wherever they existed. By the eve of the Union there were  parliamentarians, some  hereditary peers,  "shire" or county commissioners, and  burgh commissioners.The rough head count at the time reckoned that the majority of the parliament would be agin the deal, which is where blatant bribery was employed to buy votes and pay spies and agents provocateurs, pound, sterlingof which was distributed by the Earl of Glasgow.As Robert Burns famously put it, ldquoSuch a parcel of rogues in a nation they were ldquobought and sold for English gold.By then, the Scottish and English thrones had been united under one monarch for more than  years, since the Union of the Crowns in , when James Vl also became king of England when Queen Elizabeth died childless.James was Mary, Queen of Scots son, although he hadnrsquot seen her since he was an infant. The doomed Mary, taking advantage of May Day, wassailing and general drunkenness in Lochleven Castle where she was being held a prisoner in , managed to escape and head south. She was heedless of her advisers telling her not to go to London and she ended up, of course, heidless.May , eight years earlier, had seen theof John Knox from exile to lead the Scottish Reformation. And as Gandhi would probably have said had he been around to be asked: ldquoI think that would be a good idea.Knox believed that having a woman ruler ndash as he blasted in his famous tract The First Blast of the Trumpet against the monstrous regiment of women ndash was a violation of the natural order. Following Maryrsquos escape from Lochleven he joined the chorus condemning Mary as an adulteress and murderess and for the rest of his le spoke of her as ldquothat wicked woman.May  in  was also the day the King James Version of the Bible was published in London.There have been monsters throughout Scottish history, usually of the two-legged kind. On May  in  while one of most evil in history was starting a reign of terror on his people by first taking over German trade unions, here we were looking to the north of the country and Loch Ness, not to Hitler, and the legend of the serpentine monster began.There may have been local mutterings and sightings before but when the Inverness Courier ran a story about a large ldquobeast or ldquowhale-like fish it was christened Nessie. The writer was Alex Campbell, a water bailf on the loch and part-time journalist, and the article covered an alleged sighting by Aldie Mackay of an enormous creature writhing about the water as she and her husband drove along the shore.In Campbellrsquos words, ldquoThe creature disported itself, rolling and plunging for fully a minute, its body resembling that of a whale, and the water cascading and churning like a simmering cauldron. Soon, however, it disappeared in a boiling mass of foam.Not for long, however, because it was to reappear with regularity in the years that followed, to be photographed ndash although some of the shots were hoaxes or genuine misinterpretations of innocent logs and waves ndash and see surveys and expeditions camp on the shore for months, and to be written about until this day.The latest "sighting" was in  when Apple Maps showed a satellite image of what appeared to be a -metre-long monster, although it might just have been the wake of a boat, ripples caused by seals or floating wood.On that same day in , a monster capable of both destroying the world and powering it opened in southwest Scotland. It was the Chapelcross nuclear station on a former Second World War airfield near Annan, commissioned to produce weapons-grade plutonium for the UKrsquos weapons programme and also to generate power for the National Grid.The plant was decommissioned in  but the final demolition and site clearance wonrsquot be complete until at least , but more likely the new century. Hope yoursquore around for that.On May  in , the first Hillman Imp rolled off the production line at the new Rootes factory at Linwood. It was meant to compete with the highly-successful Mini, but it was hastily designed and badly executed. It was rear-engined and handled badly ndash some customers placed a bag of cement under the front bonnet to keep it stable ndash and it had an inadequate cooling system, gearbox and clutch problems, faulty chokes and a tendency to leak water. No surprise the Imp developed a reputation for unreliability.It wasnrsquot all bad as it provided work in an industry-ravaged area although that was not to last and, in , the company donated  Imps, painted green and white, for Celtic fans to drive to Lisbon to watch their team lt the European Cup.After  years it was over ndash ldquoLinwood no more as the Proclaimers sang in Letter From America ndash when Chrysler, which had taken over from Rootes, closed the factory and, in its words, put an end to that ldquodamned poorly-designed automobile. And damned the , or so who were directly or indirectly employed by the company to the dole queue.Another carmaker, Henry Ford, said that history is bunk. The future isnrsquot looking so bright either.

title: talking-rabbish-right---new-laws-land
story: In particular, Irsquod suggest three measures to be strictly enforced by police officers properly primed by watching The Sweeney and other procedural shows from the halcyon days when informal beatings were an essential part of criminal investigations.The first measure relates to my one-person campaign against horticultural racket. Irsquove no idea why this remains a one-man campaign. Am I the last person on Earth with ears, or at least a degree of sensitivity Well, Irsquom here to give the racketeers an ear-bashing, though first Irsquod better rsquofess up: I myself have an electric Flymo and I know how to use it. Irsquove tried ious hand-propelled mowers and theyrsquore all rubbish. Flymo gets the job done quickly, or ought to. Irsquove heard folk spend three hours with them on lawns the size of postage stamps.The strictures on mowers will also apply to electronic or petrol-driven trimmers, strimmers, bishers, bashers and boshers. Some folk seem unable to do anything unless itrsquos driven by electricity or petrol. Irsquom sure I saw, though it may have been in a dream, electric nose-pickers in BQ.Worse even than horticultural hellishness are DIY drills, piercing the air and driving up the blood pressure of all around. Itrsquos true. Reported this week, a study by German researchers found exposure to racket can cause long-term health implications, not just high blood pressure but potentially also cancer.No wonder. In many city suburbs and country villages, the racket is relentless. Well, itrsquoll have to relent.Under my measure, the racketeers will be allocated what theyrsquoll no doubt consider Happy Hour in which to make a daily din: say  to pm, extended maybe to  to am and  to pm on Saturdays nothing at all on the Sabbath. Failure to observe this restriction will result in one day of imprisonment for every minute of racket.Before coming to my second democratic authoritarian measure, on a related horticultural matter Irsquom also advocating that people with gardens who donrsquot appreciate them, except as racket-zones, should be moved into flats.Similarly, many country people should be relocated to urban council housing schemes, where theyrsquoll be happier among their own sort, listening to rap and making a hullabaloo.My second measure involves the confiscation and destruction of any time piece costing more than pound. I was appalled ndash becoming my default state ndash to read about Good Morning Britland presenter Ben Shephard sporting a series of fancy watches, the cheapest costing pound, and the dearest over pound,.This is disgraceful. On that manrsquos wrist is a device costing more than three times an unemployed personrsquos annual benefits. Well, soon, Big Ben will be forced to watch his luxury gewgaws being ground into the dust by properly trained goons in hi-vis jackets.My third liberal authoritarian measure will outlaw spitting. This splashed onto the news agenda with talk of the resumption of football, where the practice is re.Well, soon, any player expectorating can expect to be gobsmacked by a three-match ban. Theyrsquoll have to swallow their pride along with whatever other glutinous agglomeration apparently accumulates periodically in their gobs.I trust such inhumane but necessary measures will enjoy popular backing though I suspect that, as usual, mine will be a voice howling in the wilderness ndash whereupon someone will open a window and tell me to keep the noise down.Stay home foreverHATE to say it but those of us who work from home and never get holidays are now able to say to the rest of you: ldquoSuck it up, you suckers. Now you know what itrsquos like.Sadly, however, the holiday market is preparing itself for theof normality, loosely defined. For many young persons, itrsquos a trip to Spainrsquos ldquoparty islands where, under normal, flaky circumstances, much drink would be consumed by holidaymakers wearing shorts and other louche leisure apparel.Personally, Irsquod regard such holidays as a punishment, but maybe thatrsquos just me again: Irsquove never knowingly got into the party spirit. My idea of hedonism is a family bag of Revels.The unfortunate risk for revellers is that the firms currently offering bargain hols from  June onwards wonrsquot be refunding doshthe lockdown is still continuing by then.Irsquom happy to provide a public service and reiterate the advice of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office: ldquoWe advise against all but essential international travel. That is excellently put, and we must hope the advice remains for ever, with the omission of the words ldquobut essential.FIVE THINGS WE LEARNED THIS WEEKTHE skies are getting bluer. Prof William Collins of the University of Reading says the recent reduction in traffic pollution has left skies looking their natural colour: deep, tropical blue. There you are: every cloud has a silver lining.THIS year sees the ,th anniversary of the Battle of Thermopylae, where  Spartans held outagainst  million Persians. The event is still studied by military strategists today, with many concluding the  should have legged it.THE citizens of ancient Pompeii were keen recyclers, according to US archaeologists. Rubbish was reused for filling earth floors and other building work. Pity the poor folk never got the chance to put volcanic ash in the right recycling bin.METEOROLOGISTS have discovered the earliest reliable written record of somebody being killed by a meteorite falling on their heid. Manuscripts in Turkish archives reveal a bloke was killed in Iraq in . What are the chances, eh  One in , apparently.A STUDY by American researchers found that over-s were best prepared for the collapse of civilisation. They were most likely to have stockpiled food, water, a torch, candles, battery-powered radio, and first aid kit. Wot, no jigsaws Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions.
